description:
I first went here about 5 years ago, and have meaning to come back since as it was delicious. 

My 2018 reunion with Cafe Ethiopia reminded me that some things are as good in real life as in nostalgia. Granted: this is the only Ethiopian place I've ever been to, so take that as you want. Regardless, as a sourdough fanatic I am enthralled by injera, the thin, spongey, deliciously sour bread used as utensil and plate. The items that we had on top: beeftartar (forget the name)& hamil with cottage cheese and lentil, potato, & splitpea. Added yogurt on the side, a glass of red, it was great. 

Beyond posters, art, and tiles of Ethiopian people, there's not a ton of 'atmosphere' and it feels like a family-owned restaurant. Nothing wrong with that-- just don't expect a fast meal.
author: Julia B.

description: Solid Ethiopian food. Don't have to trek to the TL or Oakland! We got the veggie combo and beef tibs. Tibs were solid. Loved the cabbage, carrot, and potato (by far my favorite veggie Ethiopian dish). The red lentil dish was too strong on the spice, so it wasn't as flavorful. Collard greens solid.
author: Sherry L.

description:
The menu was confusing and our server wasn't very helpful, but despite that, and the restaurant's semi-drab looking appearance, the food was incredible! 

All of the prices on the menu are per person and our selections were delivered to our table on one large plate for sharing, honoring the traditional Ethiopian ritual of breaking injera and eating from the same plate to facilitate loyalty and friendship. It was somewhat tricky telling the different stew-like selections apart, but luckily everything tasted great, so it wasn't a problem. Our dish was accompanied by a bowl of rolled injera, the wheat risen flat bread, which looked like a pancake, but tasted more like a wet, sour, spongey bread. Each of us drank the Ethiopian lager with our meals, which I personally didn't care for. 

They are happy to serve on a separate dish for vegetarian selections, which ended up being a wise decision considering how I mentioned everything looked very similar and we weren't able to tell them apart. The menu does offer a few combination choices; however, they are fairly basic and all of the exciting options we wanted to combine would have been a significant extra charge; seems like that may have been conveniently planned. With the combo platters and extra add ons, this can add up to quite an expensive adventure. But overall, it was a fun and tasty dining experience with our hands that I would be happy to try again!
author: McKenna P.

description: The food here is amazing and full of flavor! Must visit this place if you are in the area. Family owned and operated. Give it a try, you won't be disappointed... well maybe, if you are in a hurry because the service is a little on the slow side, but trust me it's worth it. The folks are friendly, the food is great and who doesn't like to eat with their hands.
author: Nin J.

description:
Lovely spot for Ethiopian. My vegetarian combo place was great( do this instead of getting just one dish) my husband got the meat and veg one so we shared a bit. Family style is nice. The lemonade was Minute Maid, I thought it would be fresh, and we got just one ice cube. 
Everything was super flavorful...
author: Nils H.

description: I thought the restaurant was pleasant, but the service was very slow, and the restaurant was basically empty when we were there. Overall, I care more about the food, and the food just didn't blow me away. We ordered a couple of meat items, which were cooked well but seemed to lack that punch I was hoping for. It was similar for the vegetable dishes. They all tasted fine, but I would have wanted them to have more spice. I left feeling full but not that satisfied.
author: Sonia S.

description: I suggest you get the kitfo dish and the vegetarian combo. The vegetarian combo comes with three vegetarian dishes that you get to choose. I suggest the lentils, and potato dish. I wasn't a huge fan of the split peas. Overall, the experience was great:)
author: Lense E.

description:
The veggie combo for two, plus two meats on a separate plate, was more than enough food for four people. And it was delicious: I kept eating until one of my dining companions pointed out we were the last people in the restaurant and it was past closing time. Time flies when you're ingesting injera. Or at least when I am.

Nice vibe, with art throughout. Quick service: We were eating less than 10 minutes after ordering, unusually fast for Ethiopian restaurants I've been to.

Request: Please add Hakim Stout to your drink list, now that you have its logo on your tables!
author: Carl B.

description:
I went recently to give this place another shot and the food was just okay. You can tell the combos were heated up in a microwave, not fresh. If you order a unique dish, it tastes a little better. 

The restaurant is usually pretty empty so getting a table isn't a problem. I think there is a lot they can do with the food and service to really bring this place to the next level. Even the service seems kind of resigned and unmotivated. I've been rooting this place on for years but not a lot has changed.
author: M K.

description: Excellent cuisine.  Simply first-rate lamb, chicken and distinctly African veggie dishes.  Had the 'feel' of comfort food.  Old style Chinese village comfort food, come to think of it.  One of us introduced other family members to Tej, a delicious honey wine.  You can down a glass and still be able to function as a designated driver (but, uh, better keep it at one glass).  Cordial and courteous, though very slow service: took way too long for our dishes to finally arrive.  Obviously understaffed.  Another reviewer referred to the interior decor and ambiance as 'drab,' but it really was not.  Tastefully arranged paintings & art pieces on the well-lit walls.  They did not rush us to finish up, the way many places do these days. Will certainly make repeat visits, for sure. BTW, you'll just have to put up with the challenge of having to find parking space in that part of the Mission.  Best to go during daylight hours.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Customer service was amazing and the food was even better. First time trying Ethiopian food and it most definitely won't be the last. Will plan to come again!
author: Rogelio R.

description:
Delicious food with great vegan/vegetarian options! Loved the flavors and diversity of veggies to pick from. Our favorites were the chickpea (Shuro) and split pea (Alecha Ater). The Injera which is a staple of the meal was super yummy too. 

Only downside to this place was the service felt a little slow, especially for a weeknight when we went. There seemed to only be 1 server. Luckily with good company it can be tolerated as we enjoyed the good food; however, it was noticed that the attention to tables was spread thin. 

Prices are pretty on par with other restaurants in the Valencia corridor. 

Would definitely go back.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Food was pretty good. The restaurant was extremely hot and stuffy making the experience a little less enjoyable. Warning the honey wine is extremely sweet and hard to drink.
author: Ashley K.

description: I don't know why it took us so long to try this place.  I love going to the Mission and eating at restaurants that remind me of the Mission from my childhood: a diverse selection of ethnic cuisines in a family, local, casual and non-designer atmosphere.  The food was absolutely delicious, homey and non-pretentious which is so difficult to find in the neighborhood these days.  I would very highly recommend this for a mid-week, low key and healthy night out.  The vegetarian dishes are fantastic.
author: Adrian C.

description: The food is amazing. BUT (and this is a big one) the door chime NEVER STOPS BEEPING. It makes it a truly unpleasant place to eat. I went in again recently to see if they had changed the door. Nope.
author: Antonia T.

description: This was amazing. Get the chicken drumsticks and lamb and veggies and whatever else you want because it's probably good too. Perfect blend of spices. Excellent service!
author: Josh P.

description: I love this place. Family owned and run. The fish dish is the very BEST and I cannot seem to order anything else!!!
author: T F.

description: Everything was delicious and full of flavor! Favorites were the red lentil and chicken drumsticks.
author: Lace C.

description:
I feel bad only giving three stars because you can tell this is a family establishment, but I really think they can step it up.

1- Food was good, not great. Portions are on the smaller side. Potato veggie dish was probably our favorite.

2- large restaurant with lots of places to sit.

3- all drink come in cans, i know some people prefer that to fountain drinks.

Only 3 stars because the service was so slow when the restaurant was almost empty. It was cool to eat with our hands, but we werent even offered utensils or a knife to cut some of the bigger chunks of food up. The bathroom was also really dirty and the restaurant was very dark inside. I probably will not return.
author: Kimia M.

description: Food was good when we finally got it. Our waiter was nice but forgot half of our order the energy in there was slow and depressing. The person that looked like he was in charge was going out of his way to not get eye contact with any customers he just made the 2 female waiters do everything. All and all the food was good it took a long time to get it but I have always experienced a little longer then normal wait in Ethiopian restaurants but, the service was sad and depressing not what I wanted for a nice b day dinner with friends. I wanted to give it a one but the 2 waiters were good hearted and tried but lacked direction and training.
author: Weyland W.

description: Family owned so I recommend giving your local business a try, the food is yum! Service isn't great but there are minimal waits on weekends which is rare for the area. The prices are a bit high but if you come with a few people you can split a few things and have more fun. I loved the red lentils and the boneless chicken! Would most likely come back to try more food, glad I like spicy because it seems you can't really adjust the spice level on the things labeled "hot"
author: Hana S.

description: I have loved this place for 20 years.  The food is always good. We order the vegetarian combination (bersin is my favorite), and sometimes the beef cubes. The family that own the place is lovely- the woman is always kind. It's become my kid's favorite family restaurant. It always feels calm and unchanging in this charmed restaurant
author: Arienne A.

description:
I was once an Ethiopian food virgin. After eating dinner at Cafe Ethiopia this past weekend, my taste buds are no longer as innocent as they once were. Verdict? Ethiopian food is FANTASTIC. I'm planning on going back again soon to re-experience the party in my mouth. 

If you're an Ethiopian food noob like me, here's how it works: They give you a plate with a giant, thin, sourdough crepe-thing called "injera". Then they spoon in each dish (typically of stew-consistency) into the middle of the injera. To eat the food, you tear bits of injera off the sides and use them to wrap around pieces of meat in the middle. They also give you extra injera on the side if you don't happen to have enough. No utensils -- so make sure you wash your hands before eating! 

I came here for a friend's birthday with about 10 people, and we ordered a LOT of food: the Tsebhi Derho (chicken drumsticks), Tibsie Sega (beef cubes sauteed in butter), Zigni (lean beef chunks), Gored Gored (beef chunks simmered in butter), and more. I was happy with every single dish we ordered, but the chicken drumsticks were my absolute favorite. The chicken was tender and flavorful, and the hard-boiled egg helped balance out the meal with some neutral taste. My only gripe about this food was the bones. Using my hands to separate the meat from the bones (for splitting between our whole party) was quite difficult. 

As for the somewhat low average rating for this place, I'm sure lots of complaints were directed towards the long wait on the food. Also, the service was pretty inattentive (their water refilling frequency was terrible), but the staff was certainly among the friendliest I've had in a restaurant: think mom-and-pop style. 

I'm an absolute fan of this place, and would definitely recommend any newbie to make a dinner visit. Don't be afraid to get your hands dirty! 

TIP: If you're a fan of wine and/or sweet drinks, make sure to try out the honey wine! It pairs well with the meal and is a nice breath of fresh air between the intense flavors of the dishes.
author: Christine L.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. At this point, I've eaten here over a dozen time and the food is always exquisite. I highly recommend the veggie combo, especially Misir Wot (spicy red lentils). Also highly recommend the shredded beef and honey wine. You will definitely never be disappointed here.
author: Deena K.

description:
I'm glad I didn't look at the rating before I went here. This is way better than the last Ehtopian restraunt I went to.

Service was a bit odd thought. Not bad per say but... I don't know. Friendly but sometimes offputting? Inconsistent? Suspicious of me? It's hard to pinpoint it. Once again, it wasn't as bad as the last restraunt I went to. I was a little taken a back though when the woman serving me did not greet me and only said, "No dogs in the restraunt." I use a service dog (and a cane sometimes which I was using then) and told her so which she seemed kind of resentful about. I think she may be afraid of dogs as she tried to refill my glasses of water by standing as far away from my table as possble and reaching her arms in an arc as if to remain as high above my dog as possible. Thanfully she calmed down when she realized I was quiet and polite and all my dog intended to do was nap on top of my backpack while I ate.

The food was really good. Not the best I've ever had but so far the best I've had lately in San Francisco or Berkeley. The tastes were well rounded and nothing on my veggie combo was anything short of good. The Injara was not oversalted like in some places and so it was good with the food. The warm food was served warm at this place (which has been an issue at other restraunts I've been to, particularly family ones with only one or two servers). 

The portions here are smaller than some Ehtopian restraunts in SF but the prices are, too.... but really, does one really need to sit down and eat three meals in one sitting because you got a veggie combo on one's own. I finished it but I was pushing myself because it was good. It's certainly enouh to fill one up for a meal, possibly a bit too much.

I got offered a fork too which she seemed almost relieved I didn't take. She pretty much forgave the fact I had the service dog she had to let in at that point. I guess she has a lot of people coming in there that are even less familiar with Ethopian food than I who are demanding forks. I did have to ask her for napkins though. She forgot to check if I needed more water but after the first polite ask she was on the ball refilling it as needed.

They're honest here, too. A customer left his wallet and she got it back to him with all the contents there. He thanked her and told her he couldn't wait until the next time he ate there.

The decor here leaves something to be desired (continuity or a theme of some sort perhaps) but the place is clean. There's was some music on--- it was in Gaelic when I was there which was sort of a cultural contrast but it wasn't disruptive. The place was mostly empty despite the lunch rush.

It's probably more liike 4 or 4.5 stars but was generous and rounded up because the ratings of this place don't accurately tell you how good the food is.

Service could use some work. Food is solid. Decor could use some unified intent/theme and decluttering. Clean. Nice little family business.
author: A J.

description:
Found this treasure amongst all the authentic Mexican places in the Mission area. Definitely thought it was great. I don't get to eat Ethiopian food often because ironically enough, it's very hard to find. 

The setting is a big plate that you share (if you go with someone else, which I highly recommend). You eat with your hands, which is awesome! The bread that they give you is nothing like naan, so don't expect it to be sweet. It definitely goes well with the meal though. I had the chicken plate while I shared that with my brother who had the fish plate. 

Super yummy and would recommend to everyone! Very affordable as well.
author: Rachael J.

description:
My friends and I were looking up places in SF to eat and we came across this restaurant on Yelp! I've never had Ethiopian food so I can't quite say it's the best Ethiopian food I've had. My friend said that this place made her re-like Ethiopian food, so that's definitely a plus! I just thought that the value wasn't that great. 

Food: For four people, we ordered three dishes - Tsebhi Derho (chicken drumsticks), Lamb Tsebhi Begee (lamb), and Yatakelt Kilikil (potatoes, carrot and cabbage). There were literally two chicken drumsticks to our surprise. The flavors were delicious but there just wasn't enough meat considering they're about $15 a dish. The enjera was a little soft and sour flatbread that got some getting used to. Compared to all the dishes, I think eating the enjera got me the most full. All three dishes came in bowls and then were placed by the waiter onto the enjera family style. There was additional enjera so we wrapped the main courses in them by hand, no utensils!

Service: I will say, we got in probably 20 minutes before they closed, so it was nice that they still allowed us to come in to eat! It just sucked since we forgot they were closing, that when we tried to order more food, they told us that the kitchen had closed. 

Overall: It was a great experience and a wonderful first introduction to Ethiopian food. Value-wise, I didn't like how little food there was for a $15 dish.
author: Ada C.

description: Cafe Ethiopia saved the day, deliciously. We were running late, hungry and frustrated and with barely thirty minutes to spare before our show at the Marsh. We'd been looking forward to eating at Cafe Ethiopia but were doubtful it would be possible in such a small window of time. We explained the situation to the server, and she was gracious and relaxed and made it happen. The vegetarian combo was intensely delicious, the location pleasant and convenient, the service kind and professional, and the experience a memorably positive one. I can't wait to go back and savor the food as it deserves!
author: lauren r.

description:
This is by far my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco! I've been eating here for years when I come to visit my dear friend who lives in the neighborhood. The food is good, fresh, flavored and spiced well. The people running the cafe are so kind and sweet. The prices are affordable.
The veggie combo is the way to go! And the spiced tea.
author: Aisha M.

description:
Is it really so adventurous to try delicious Ethiopian food? Heck no, and here's why: everyone likes chicken, many people like lamb/beef/fish, vegetarian options up the wazoo exist here as well, plus there is wine special to the culture! What more could you ask for?

In a very hands-on (no silverware used) method involving scooping various dishes up with injera rolls -- a spongy sourdough flatbread -- we were served the following:

-Meat and Vegetarian Combo: Tsebhi Derho (Doro Wat) (Chicken Drumsticks), Lamb Tsebhi Begee (Beg Wat) and Hamili (Gomen) (Collard Greens)
-Tibsie Assa (Sautéed Fish)
Fish sauteed with hot pepper sauce, tomatoes, onions and seasoning
-Bottle of Enat Tej Ethiopian Style Honey Wine

SPECIFIC COMBO ITEMS:
-Tsebhi Derho (doro Wat)
Chicken drumsticks gently simmered in berbere sauce
-Lamb
Tsebhi begee (yebeg wat), fresh and tender lamb with bones cooked with hot pepper and seasoning
-Collard Greens
Sautéed in butter, tomatoes, onions and berbere sauce

A carnivorous tyrannosaur I am, but surprisingly, my 2nd favorite dish was the collard greens! I kept going back for it -- riveted my tastebuds. My absolute favorite dish was the Tibsie Assa (fish), extremely flavorful and vivid.

Everything else did still taste good, just had to watch out for bones. Lamb was gamey but it was cooked as it would have been in that culture, so that was welcomely expected.

We could not get enough of the Honey Wine, made locally! Believe it was from Oakland. Definitely recommend it.

I appreciated the rich decor that surrounded us, from artwork painted directly on the pillars to flags and pictures hanging. Wonderful.

Have been here twice now, as well as to additional Ethiopian restaurants in the state. This was my first tasting location ever. Let this be yours, too.
author: Garett T.

description:
First-time here never had Ethiopian food.
The food was really good
Small portions 
Service was good
Would I ever come back
Maybe I have to be in the mood
author: Manuel H.

description:
This place was popping a few nights ago when I went for dinner.

My friends and I decided to give it a try. A group of 10 of us stepped and so naturally it took some time to get seated.

My friends had never eaten Ethiopian food so there was some confusion as to why we received no forks, no chips, no bread...but I was not fooled since I'm a pro at this.

The food was fairly food but I'm docking a few stars since two people in our group asked if the food was spicy. They were told it was not spicy. The food came very spicy. I could handle the spice but these two friends were unable to eat anything at all.
author: Ernesto G.

description: The ambience is a little stark but plenty of seating . The staff always seems friendly and accommodating.  Not sure what people are complaining about in terms of spice - my daughter is super spice phobic and she eats and enjoys the food. Also the whole wondering about not being offered utensils? If you feel compelled to use utensils ask for them- I don't think mind reading is included in the description of " good service". Sure the bathrooms could use a little spruce ( this is something that I often judge a restaurant by and will stay away from places that seem not to value hygiene .) however the food is tasty and authentic so I give them a pass.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
We hadn't had Ethiopian for a while, so stopped by Cafe Ethiopia around 8 pm on a Wednesday night. They offer good options for vegetarians -- lots of choices -- and ample if not enormous portions. We did not have to wait for a table, service was fast and friendly, and pricing competitive.

I see some people are lowballing CE because of silly reasons, like the annoying buzzer that goes off whenever someone walks in. Do not be dissuaded! Cafe Ethiopia is a local gem, and Ethiopian cuisine is both nutritious and fun (where else can you eat lentils without utensils, hands only?)
author: joanne g.

description:
Looong overdue to review. I went with a group of friends after they raved about it. It was actually after the night I started working on my half sleeve, so I was in kind of a weird post tattoo euphoria. 

I had never had Ethiopian food but was beginning to embark on more exotic foods than I had been eating so I figured I'd give it a go. There were I think 8 of us and we ordered lamb, steak, and lentils, among other items which all sat atop a huge piece of spongy Injera that you tear off and eat like tiny tacos.  

It's a cool eat with your hands experience that I think everyone should experience. Plus everything is cheap as dirt and tastes amazing.
author: Crystal C.

description: I love Ethiopian food and since this is the closest option to my house, I most often eat here. I've hit just about every Ethiopian restaurant in the Bay Area and am happy to give this place 5 stars! The food is delicious, prices and portions are good (cheaper than other places even), nice family and good service. I've never had a bad experience in my 10+ years of coming here, I'm also not one to complain about the ambiance of a restaurant. It's a family owned business that, thankfully, hasn't been wiped out by the rapid gentrification of Valencia St. Some of my favorites are the kitfo, lamb tibs, and whole lentils.
author: Anna H.

description:
I like this place. People that gave it less than 5 stars are dead stupid. 

It's Ethiopian food so it's not shit you eat with your hands. What do you think they do in ethiopia when they have larger chunks of food? Pull it apart from their hands. Soda in cans? They didn't offer utensils? Christ, first world problems. 

The food here is great. Their injera is well made and I find the food great for their home-family style meals. If you dont want your meats to touch with veg options, open your mouth and tell them. Traditionally, they don't deal with people who are so high maintenance.

I give this place 5 stars because they deliver good comfort food and walking in an empty restaurant makes me feel VIP. Bam!
author: Reina T.

description: Very good Ethiopian food. I have tried most of their dishes over the years and all are solid. My to go dishes are a combination of Tibsi, chicken or beef and a combo of several veggie dishes.
author: Lo F.

description:
Mehh....

service is nonexistent. Not necessarily bad just not there. At all. Food portions are smaller than any other Ethiopian joint I've been to. The food itself is super sub par. I had the veggie sampler, the #4 beef cubes with butter, tomato and spices, and the #10 chicken and mushroom. Both meat dishes were overcooked and dry. The flavor tasted great, gotta give them that. But I won't be back. I recommend checking out Oasis Cafe!
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Smelled great when we walked by, so we had to try. Solid Ethiopian food. Not *the best*, so saving the 5 stars for places that really stand out. But still very enjoyable.

Several vegan options -- no butter oil (ghee) used in any of the veggie dishes. Enjera is part wheat and part teff. Decent (if dated) ambiance with some cool Ethiopian memorabilia.
author: Alec F.

description: Great neighborhood staple.Been coming here for years and never had a bad meal or experience. It's an authentic, family run business which I love. They don't always check on you but that's ok, not everyone is as HM as the tech folks.
author: Claire K.

description: Quaint Ethiopian restaurant on Valencia. Good food and fast service! The other Ethiopian restaurant I frequent takes almost half an hour to bring out the food. This place is quick and hits the spot.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
We came here on a Friday night with a group of 5. No wait and our server was friendly. My partner and I just moved from dc where Ethiopian food is rampant. The food here was good. I highly recommend the lamb tibs. The portion is a little bit smaller but filling and well-priced. 

I give it a 4 because it's definitely worth trying and most of the low ratings below are from people who seem like they've never had Ethiopian food "sourdough crepe" and being offended when not offered a fork
author: Josephine L.

description:
I can't believe we found this gem just by walking by and taking a chance! I didn't even consult Yelp beforehand and I'm so glad. This is definitely some of the best Ethiopian I've ever had. 

I'm a big fan of doro wat- spicy chicken legs with yogurt and eggs. Try the meat and veggie sampler platter so you can taste a few dishes and find one you love! My favorite is the gomen- collard greens! Tear off some injera (spongy bread) and lay it on your food then scoop up a portion. I think you'll love it! 

The staff aren't the most verbose but they're efficient and helpful. If you'd prefer not to do it the traditional way and eat with your hands, just ask them for a fork! No big deal! (But it's super fun to try it that way!)
author: Guinnevere C.

description:
We were group of 12 people visiting this restaurant for dinner. Most of love Ethiopian food and are regulars at Zeni - a south bay based Ethiopian restauant. 

I am not an expert at Ethiopian food, but I do know that food at Zeni's tastes way better than food here. We ordered almost every vegetarian dish as parts of 2 combo injeras- chard,potato,cabbage and carrot,yellow lentils,eggplant..

our meat loving friends had zigni and the collard greens in chicken. The person who had zigni loved it, but the person who had the chicken was not impressed.

The injera itself tasted very sour as compared to the one's I have had earlier. And we all noticed that they didn't serve sambusas which are a faovrite ethiopian appetizers for this group. 

We did try the Honey wine and it was good. The ambiance is nice, roomy and welcoming, service is slow and lethargic, location is awesome. All my favorite boutiques around. Will not mind coming here as I do have ethiopian cravings more often than not, but do not think that they are among the best..
author: Harsha G.

description:
Not impressed at all. Maybe I was expecting more from a place in the Mission. Food was seriously overpriced, portions tiny, and worst of all bland, bland, bland. 

How can Ethiopian food be bland?!!!

Service did not make up for the lack in the food. It was very slow and the place was almost empty.

We were so excited to visit and eat in the Mission too. Next time we're going for the Mexican. We eat Mexican all the time, but we probably won't strike out with Mexican in the Mission!
author: Nora S.

description: I would say this is the worst Ethiopia restaurant I have ever been from customer service to food . Me and my friends stopped by first time. No one welcomed us, we stood at door for a while even thou the manger/ owner saw us .  Finally sat down and order food and drink , and we didn't like test of the honey wine and asked if we can switch to Ethiopian beer , she said she is still going to charge us even thou we didn't drink it . So paid $17 drink we didn't drink also , we asked to speak because it wasn't right to charge customer that we didn't drink . When we asked to speak owner from sudden she got busy didn't want talk to us . Also she was asking customer next to our table who were white how the food was and heard saying enjoy but never came to our table . We left the restaurant and called back to speak to the manager, but lady who answered the phone, I believe her daughter has kept saying , owner is busy she we could leave message of not she was going to hang up the phone and she did . If u are u Ethiopia do go there .
author: Abraham G.

description:
The food at Café Ethiopia is good.  I ordered the veggie combo (carrots, potatoes, cabbage, yellow split peas, and spicy lentils) and ate the entire thing.  The portion size is smaller from the other Ethiopian/Eritrean places I've dined in, but the price is reflective.  It was about $1-$2 cheaper here.

The décor and atmosphere are minimal.  They focus everything on the food, I suppose.  The waitress was friendly and attentive.

The only issue I had was the cleanliness of the bathroom.  I wash my hands before every meal, especially if I'm eating Ethiopian food.  It wasn't the cleanest, and it was very, very small.  The trash can is literally right in front of your face.. Maybe if I was taller it wouldn't have felt so close.

It' the only Ethiopian restaurant in the Mission.  It's worth a try if that's what you're craving.
author: Vira P.

description:
I was introduced to this place last year and have been a regular customer since. I never ate Ethiopian food before and this place is where I started. 

I love this place despite everyone's opinion lol I usually get minced beef, chicken and mushrooms, and 2 orders of the potatoes, carrots, and cabbage dish. OMG. BOMB. 

However, service is a bit on the slow scale but if you appreciate the anticipation as well as appreciating well prepared food, then there's no problem. They are also hiring ;) and the restroom is pretty CLEAN. I will also add better pics soon ;))
author: rosanna b.

description: We got the vegi sampler, and honey wine. We both liked the honey wine. I liked the meal. My wife described it as plain. The 'crepe' bread has a salty / yeasty flavor like some german bread. I like their decor too.
author: Glenn R.

description: I love Ethiopian food but this restaurant, which is the most convenient to where I live, is not my favorite. I keep going back hoping it will change and sometimes it actually IS good but usually it is VERY mediocre: small portions, bland food, and bad service. By bad service I mean that the owners, especially the man, are depressed and never seem to remember us or smile ever. They have a good ambiance except for the door beeping by the one table every time someone enters. I think I'll travel a little further to find better Ethiopian food.
author: Josie L.

description:
Some friends wanted to get dinner and one of them suggested this place.

The place itself is pretty simple and the service is okay. Menu is pretty big and the portions are hearty.

Everyone was vegetarian except for me so I was kind of pushed into getting a vegetarian plate. We decided to get 3 vegetarian platters so we could have one of each vegetarian dish. 

I honestly don't remember the name of everything, but I really liked the swiss chard, the potatoes, and one other thing..I can't explain. Everything was spiced just right! I forgot my initial irritation about being forced to get vegetarian. Everything was yummy. 

I love that you share the meal in a giant plate and eat with your hands too!
author: Sofia R.

description:
Omg the food is excellent here as well as the beer and wine. The host showed me how to eat the food as well.
He even introduced me to Ethiopian beer and wine, which was really good stuff. It makes me wonder why their beers and wines are not sold in a super market.
I can eat at this place everyday. They had comedy playing on the speakers that was actualy funny. Ala in all I totally enjoyed myself, and would recomend Cafe Ethiopia to everyone.
author: Jason M.

description:
Back when I was in the Mission more I dropped by Cafe Ethiopia for some tasty fare.

Their veggie dish was fantastic, though their Injera was rather thin and tore easily. Compared to Gojo in San Jose, this is more of a 3, but for SF it's one of the better and more authentic places in the vicinity.

They didn't serve milk and honey, mores the pity and parking is absolutely dreadful. But the wait was quick, the service was friendly and thoughtful.

If I'm in the area and craving Ethiopia food, here is definitely where I go! :D
author: Meg T.

description:
The worst costumer service I seen in Ethiopian restaurant. Every where I went they have the best service and happy face 
 The food was ok. But the beer which is st. George Ethiopian beer he over charge $ 14.00 dollars each bottler. I go to different Ethiopian restaurant in bay area the price is $4.50 I am surprised why he charge triple prose it is ripped of he didn't tell the price or he didn't put the price on the menu. 
Sir, please could you learn how to treat costumer
author: Sun W.

description:
An interesting experience, but not one I want to repeat.

I was not impressed with the restaurant, the food, or the service. There is a high-pitched alarm on the entrance door that beeps loudly three times whenever anyone enters or leaves. For me, this alone would make the place a never-visit-again experience.
 
Service was slow and unenthusiastic. In fairness, we were in a hurry and it may have seemed worse than it really was.

Food was served on a huge sourdough crepe, which was something new for us. People who know what they're doing grab the food with a piece of the pancake.  We used forks and a serving spoon but even when you aren't struggling to eat it, the food wasn't anything to get excited about.
author: James V.

description:
The food here was pretty good, and the service pretty lousy.  

We really liked our drumstick chicken, beef curry, and red lentils.  The lamb was too fatty and rich for us, and the cubed chicken was a bit dry.  

The waiter was a disappointment.  He never came by after serving us to ask about our meal, never offered us more bread (injera), and never refilled our water glasses.

We might be back for the delish cubed beef and drumstick chicken, but this definitely isn't the best Ethiopian place I've been to.
author: Barnali D.

description:
The food here was just delicious! We got the injera with the no.2 chicken and the no. 14 (lentils) and 15 (split peas) veg and they were outstanding-such rich flavours. It was the perfect amount for 2 people. Service was prompt and the waitress provided good recommendations.

Total came to $40 for that with a beer each which is a total bargain. Looks like a family owned restaurant which we love so we'll be back.
author: Chris D.

description: This place is great, I've never left hungry.  The food is really good and offers a great variety of flavors and textures.  A wonderful experience with good flavors
author: Jonol S.

description: I always get take-out because my husband isn't the hugest fan of Ethiopian food, but I love it! Consistently delicious.  (I tried a couple other Ethiopian places in SF & none were as good as this.)  Definitely give Cafe Ethiopia a try!
author: Emily S.

description:
A wonderful experience.  I was served both by the older gentleman and another time by the older woman and both were very nice and polite and efficient.  

I had the vegetarian combo with an extra side item one time and the second time I had the shrimp with collards and side item as well.  It was both filling and just the right amount of spice (I ordered it mild).  

The flavors of Ethiopia are something very special and close to my heart and I love so much to eat the injera bread with my hands but its nice to have that serving spoon there just in case to scrape up the last morsels of food. 

I'm trying to become vegetarian so Ethiopian food definitely helps me along my path. 

If you like spicy food and want to try a taste of Northeast Africa, come to Cafe Ethiopia.  The food is very hearty and home made and goes excellent with a glass of honey wine. 

Bravo. 

One tip to the staff & owner:  Add more vegetarian items or a bigger veggie combo with more choices :)
author: Dan R.

description: What a nice experience!  Had an enjoyable meal here. Platter of 2 meats and 3 vegetables. Lamb, chicken, greens, 2 kinds of peas plus some greens. We also tried the Ethiopian beer. Excellent. Good service and a nice atmosphere. Recommend to those who want to try something different and delicious.
author: Mike H.

description:
This was my second time having Ethiopian food, first for many of my friends that night. They said they enjoyed the experience. But personally, I thought it could've been better.

Ethiopian food is meant for sharing (family style), so we asked how big the portions are. We were told that one order is big enough for one person. Given that we had 7 girls, some who ate less than others, we decided to order 6 entrees to share.

Our server kept insisting that we order more. But his aggressive attitude made us remain firm about our 6 dishes (diced drumstick, beef cube, tender lamb, sautéed fish, pureed lentils and sautéed eggplant).

The food was good. Each person had their own favorites. However, I was very disappointed with the portions. Our platter was huge, covered in ingera. But each entrée was only a handful size serving. How is a scoop of meat and a piece of ingera a large enough portion for one person? 

One thing I didn't like was how they moved us to the back of the restaurant because a larger party arrived and wanted our table. How rude. It really wasn't that bad until I thought I was going to pass out from the unbearable heat back there.
author: Marti L.

description: Okay food with shitty service and super over priced. One of our dishes was missing and when we asked about it they were upset at us that we were asking about it.
author: ferhat n.

description: SO GOOD!! I have been coming here for years every time I'm in SF. The food is delicious and very authentic. Very calm and quiet atmosphere separated from the hustle and bustle of the street. Love the food and the people!
author: James S.

description: Really amazing Ethiopian food. We had the lamb chops and Biseri and it was very well done. The owner is also very hospitable.
author: Suvarna K.

description: We did a walk in and received the best care in this homely, family run restaurant.  The food and service were great.  We even got a little museum tour of the cultural, historical paintings and artifacts.  We have found our Ethiopian joint in the mission!
author: Irum M.

description:
Pretty decent venture into Ethiopian cuisine with Cafe Ethiopia. 

Ordering takeout when thoughts of something we hadn't had in a while plagued us.... how about some Ethiopian?

Nice spice on the Split Lentils & the Potatoes were tasty & mild.  Portions were a tad on the small side - esp for the Lentils but given we ordered 3 dishes & weren't all that hungry to begin with, we were more than stuffed & had leftovers to boot

BF said his Chicken & Mushrooms was super hot & he loved it

Injera was spongy & a bit lemonny but mopped up the goodies just as it should have & glad we had ordered extras

Would totally consider this place again for Ethiopian takeout - A-OK!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Maybe I just don't care for Ethiopian food, and I sure as heck know I would never order it for take-out. It's a fun experience, at least. We were a group of 6 and went with the Meat & Vegetarian Combo (~$13/ person), since it seemed like the least work in deciding how the heck to make sense of the menu. Kudos for giving the entrees numbers - whiteys like me need any help I can get in that area. 

20+ minutes later, out came a giGANtic platter with injera, chard (greens), lentils, chicken, and lamb. The curried meats were SPI-SAY! The curries also stained the heck out of my mouth, my fingers, and anything within arms' reach of me. Probably not a great idea for a first date, or any dinner where you'd like to retain your dignity. Eating with my hands/ spongey bread was fun, but the service was pretty inattentive, which blows when you're dying for a water refill. Lamb was very sinewy, veggie dishes rocked. 

3 stars for the food, 2-3 for the service, 2-3 for comfort/decor ambience, 3 for prices (a little high considering what you get), and oddly 5 stars for the drinks. Hakim Stout - Ethiopian beer - and honey wine (~$5 each) were delish!

If I'm ever feeling adventurous in the Mission again, I may be back. Worth a go at least once.
author: Laura B.

description: Brought our family - we had an incredible dinner and we're all blown away with everything we ordered! #36, a spicy chickpea dish, was INSANE!!!
author: Aron K.

description:
This place used to be awesome. But upon visiting it recently, as in last night, I feel let down. In fact, most of Valencia is different now that there's all the uber hipsters and Twitter folks pouring in new "riche" money. I get it, it's good for the city, but it changes places too. 

For instance Cafe Ethiopia's service used to be prompt, but last night it was so slow. Another thing is that the portions used to be more generous. But the first thing i noticed was how much smaller everything was, the injera, the lettuce/salad that comes with the meal, and the lentils, chard, and meats were all much smaller than before. The flavor is still there, but it's changed. I'd go back if I were in the area, but I doubt I'd make the trip just to eat there like we used to.

I'm happy that they are filling the house, in the past I've only always seen the place half full, but I'm saddened that it seems they've fallen into the trap of serving less for the same price or more now that they are popular with the hipsters.
author: cg w.

description:
Ok, this is the only place in the Mission to get Ethiopian food, so I am ashamed I have to give it 2 stars.  The food was microwaved, not freshly cooked.  How do I know.  How you going to stew a chicken yet the meat inside is only medium hot, same for the sides.  If you want my money again serve me fresh food.  Ethiopian food takes some 20-30 minutes to get to your table, I was suspicious that after 9 minutes I had everything I wanted.

They can do better.  I wish Massawa was still around, sigh.
author: John L.

description:
Cafe Ethiopia is awesome!  So many items to choose from and all delicious, have tried just about every dish!  Great local restaurant, always bring our friends and family and all are impressed and want to return every time they come back to SF.

one of the most flavorful items :Chicken & Mushroom: Mushroom & chicken pieces seasoned with Tomatoes, onions and spicy sauce served ( hot or mild) 
this one is sooooo good!

If you've never tried Ethiopian cuisine.........make it a point to have lunch or dinner here.....you will love it and want to come back again and again!
author: Ken B.

description:
Remember what your wise old grandmother used to say when you were a kid? That the only good Ethiopian food in the BA was in Oakland? But did you listen? Nooooooo! You had to keep trying the joints in SF only to be disappointed time and time again! Sorry, referring to myself there. Projecting again. 

I grade Ethiopian places solely on the big goodie platter which makes up the meal. I don't care if there are alligators in the bathrooms or if the place is decorated with Nazi propaganda. 

We got the meat and veg combo for two. Instead of a plate full around the edges with goodies (Do a Google image search for "Ethiopian food") , we got a few forlorn lumps of meat, and a bit of veggies, in the middle of a mostly empty injera pizza. What was there was ok, but this one's got "Meh. I've experienced better" written all over it.
author: Nick C.

description: Delicious! Lovely staff.  Not a pretentious atmosphere. A jewel of authentic food on within all the hipster foodie eateries in the neighborhood.
author: Best M.

description:
As many reviews have said the food is great. What has not been said is the dining experience is traditional relaxing and a meal shared with people you want to have a conversation with.  This is my favorite dining experience in San Francisco. The food, drink 
and  atmosphere  is wonderful at any price. If you are gluten free ask for rice instead of ingera (traditional bread). I give it 5 stars for the entire experience.
author: Virginia. M.

description: Cafe Ethiopia is my fav. This review is really only for the vegetable combination platter. It's one of the best in the area in my opinion. It tastes way better than the one at Tadu Ethiopian. Cafe Ethiopia also has delicious honey wine. I always leave satisfied.
author: Andrea L.

description:
so a quick review of the "poor" reviews reveals 2 that jump out, with complaints of "they don't take reservations, whah!" and "it takes a long time" while admitting the food is very tasty.

Prepare yourselves folks......Good food takes more than a couple of minutes. perhaps you need to watch Brian Regan's skit on microwaving pop-tarts and loosen up your schedule.

We nearly always order the combo, at ~$12.95 it's easily two meals which is just fine by SF pricing standards, IMO. Chard, lentils, collard greens, just about all the veggies are great. I think we usually get a #2, #4, and a veg, or #2, #6, and a veg. Can't go wrong, the spice level is always just right, not "burn your mouth" hot, but more than "barely there" type of level.
   As another Yelper said, if you get to-go, one prob w/ biodegradable boxes is they won't hold the sauce so don't set it right on your lap, make sure to get a separate bag for each box so you can set it on your lap inside the bag.
  Wash your hands, enjoy, be merry.......and loosen up your schedule (or call ahead) ;)
author: Christian H.

description:
There aren't too many Ethiopian restaurants out there, and this was my first time trying out Ethiopian food. 

Their kay wat, gomen, and misir wat were all very tasty. It came with more than enough lot of the spongy ingera, and we were quite stuffed by the end.

I thought the food was quite good, but it was the wine that brought down the rating. As a fair warning -- the honey wine is NOT as good as some other brands you can buy. This could just be due to the brand that they serve at this place. My friends have said that it should be a sweet and palatable drink. However, this hardly had any honey flavor. Intsead, it was like a bittersweet, rather acoholic tasting wine. 

I would definitely come back again to try some other meat or vegetarian dishes, but I would probably avoid the Ethiopian adult beverages.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I'm not an expert, but have been eating Ethiopian for years; this is some of the tastiest I've ever enjoyed! I tend to use reviews quite often but am seldom motivated to write them; felt the need to for this restaurant.
I would highly recommend a combo plate w/ Tsebhi Derho (chicken drumsticks) and tsebhi begee (lamb on the bone) - in sauces to die for!
author: Tim C.

description:
Really good & flavorful Ethiopian food!

The good:
Dishes done right
The have that dish with dried meat that some other places don't have
Ambiance is standard for Ethiopian Restaurants.

The bad:
Slow service
Can be crowded with dates trying to be adventurous
author: M S.

description: Great Ethiopian food! Convenient location too.
author: Peter K.

description:
Ambiance: 3/5
Food: 3.5/5
Service: 2/5

I came here for dinner to meet up with my two high school buddies I haven't seen in a while.

Let me warn you, parking is SUPER unfriendly in this neighborhood. Took me close to 40 minutes to find parking!! I was about to give up and just go home, but I had already set up dinner. 

Amongst the three of us (me + 2 guys), three dishes were "just enough," but not FULFILLING. The portion size was fairly small for what we were paying. Each dish was about $12-15 dollars. 
1) Chicken & Mushroom: 3.5/5
2) Tibsie Shrimp: 3/5
3) Tibsie Sega 3.5/5

We also ordered a bottle of wine to share, a Cab. We were all a little shocked when the waitress came out with the bottle uncorked. Hmm, we were wondering if the bottle was already opened before hand or was it used already? Eh, who knows..

Total cost per person: $25 with tip and tax.
author: Jen H.

description: Pretty tasteless and over salted Ethiopian food in the Mission.
author: Josh B.

description: I went to check out this place with my sister as I never had Ethiopian food. You'll be eating with your hands most, if not all the time, when you eat here, just warning you as it can get a little messy. They only give you one napkin which is not enough. I was warned the food was going to be spicy and it did take a while before I noticed it. Anyway we started off with a avocado mixed greens salad. It was already, but only 4 small pieces of avocado in the salad. My sister ordered the Tsebhi Derho and the chicken sauce was spicy, but it was a slow to hit me at first. I ordered a Zigni (kay Wat) which was spicy Lamb. I thought it was nice is tender, but some of the meat fell off the bone already once the plate came to me so I thought I was eating just a plate of bones at first. The wait service was alright, but none of the staff even said the usual, "bye. thank you for coming" as we left.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I love Ethiopian food in general but I especially like how it is prepared at Cafe Ethiopia.  The Chicken with Mushrooms and the Chicken with Collard Greens are my favorite.

The atmosphere is low key.  I have never had to wait for a table.  The volume allows for conversation without any problem what so ever.  The service is fine.  This is not a high end restaurant where they will pamper you but this is fabulous food for a reasonable price in a clean comfortable environment.  I think it is essentially a mom and pop establishment and both "mom" and "pop" are warm but will not fawn over you.  Yes the food takes a little while but that's because it is being made fresh.
author: Shastine K.

description:
Great tasting, quality, homemade food for a good value.  There is virtually no ambiance to the restaurant, but let the food speak for itself and you'll be happy dining here.

Wine list was silly--don't look.  But the take home message here is that you should eat here, and be happy with your life because life is good (like Ethiopian food).
author: Lara W.

description:
I had cravings for Ethiopian food today.  Wife and I went to Care Ethiopia.  We were served by a kind woman - ordered the Kitfo (steak tar tar) and the wife ordered the vegetarian special.  I was expecting to  not enjoy the food based on the shitty reviews this place got from my fellow yelpers.  To our surprise the food was surprisingly good (believe me I am a Ethiopian food snob!).  The Kitfo melted in our mouths so lusciously, and the vegetarian dish was a nice compliment.  

The only negative was the price - slightly higher than what I am used to for Ethiopian food.  Also if you want extra injara bread you better cough up an extra $2.50.  Other restaurants just give it for free.  Slightly irritated by this extra $2.50/

Would we return?  Most likely yes if it were lunch time and I was absolutely craving Ethiopian food.
author: Sahad P.

description:
Finest Ethiopian food in San Francisco, if not the Eritrean heavy Bay Area.

As a vegetarian, and with friends who are strict vegan, there aren't too many excellent places to go for food in the Bay Area.  

Cafe Ethiopia is one of them.

Go eat there immediately.  Get the bersin, anything with split peas.  Flax seeds, potatoes, bersin to die for.
author: daniel f.

description:
Cafe Ethiopia has got it all. A nice and convenient location, a beautiful setup, delightful waitresses and delicious authentic Ethiopian cuisine!

I have went to many different Ethiopian restaurants in the San Francisco area, and by far, I feel really comfortable and welcomed in Cafe Ethiopia. The pictures on the walls give such a great feeling inside of connection to tradition and simple life. The food itself represents the tradition, and it is made so well I simply have a difficult time choosing what favorite dish I'd like to have, since all the food is superb! 

The injara is excellent. I like having the spinach and my girlfriend loves to have Kantishara (Mushrooms with a wonderful sauce). Eating with my hands is a blessing to my senses, and the food is such a blessing to my taste buds. 

Somehow I always go home with a happy tummy, as if joy is nourishing me.

Great place for dates, anniversaries, birthdays and simply a good meal.
author: Joel J.

description: Alright, so I profess my love for this place. Since I moved to SF, this has been a staple place for me. Not only are the owners super friendly (get to know them), but also the food is extremely delicious. I can proudly say that I have tasted every dish in this restaurant and do not have one that I dislike. In fact, I love most of them. Highly recommend this place for a great meal and a bonding experience with your friends since you will eat out of a large dish together :). Enjoy!
author: Sam K.

description: Ok,  the woman who took my order had a bad attitude. I asked for her to help me choose dishes that were not too spicy--mild ok. I asked which dishes she recommends/likes best--she says, "I LIKE ALL OF THEM OF COURSE." She responded and said that ALL the dishes had spices. I requested her to choose mildly spicy dishes for us since the boyfriend can not handle it. When we got the Meat and Veggie combo which was suppose to be $16 it was VERY VERY SPICY--even my eyes watered and I am Vietnamese (we love spicy)!! My boyfriend's mouth was on fire and requested more bread to try to eat the dish. Guess what? Apparently 2 pieces of bread = $4.00!? An order for 1 person ends up being $20--I chose a single person dish since he was not so hungry. Not to mention I had to go up to the counter to place the order AND pay the tab. No tip and we definitely will not be coming back or recommending this place.
author: Leelee E.

description:
Since Ethiopian food really isn't all that common, I came to this restaurant with excitement, an excitement of trying something new. But the experience here did not strike me positively.

We came here as a group of 8 or 9 during the afternoon, as we order, the woman serving us was quite impatient, which you can also tell from her expression. 

The food was not that good for its price, the flavors are confusing and un-distinctive, but I did like the injera bread and the fact that we can use our fingers to eat.

But now, walking out of this restaurant, I can finally tell people: "Hey! I had Ethiopian food before!"
author: David H.

description:
I'm surprised this place wasn't more crowded! It should be! Our waitress was really great to explain the menu to us, explain family style eating, and how to serve it. 

I definitely recommend the lamb (with bone). My friend got a vegetable/meat combo, and while the chickpeas were also yummy, the lamb was our favorite.
author: Ellie M.

description:
ok, I was pleasantly surprised by Ethiopian food. Great flavor, unique way of eating, yes with your hands. Whatever you order including the other person it is served on a large pancake like bread called Injera. You pull it apart and scoop up the food. The veggies were actually my favorite part and I am a carnivore for sure. Excellent flavor, fun meal. 

The restaurant is small, and good for conversation. It is not eye catching from the street, but trust the Yelpers, it is worth a stop. I will definitely be back.
author: Jeremiah K.

description: Great food, very tasty and spicy, soft meat and tender chicken in very interesting sauces eaten by hand with special kind of bread (pan fried) - more information/recommendation about dishes from waiter/owner could be better, service could be nicer.
author: Ido K.

description:
My husband and I went today.  

Pros:

Authentic decor 
Food tasted great!
Service was nice

Cons:

Portion size was too small.  The family platter which is normally covered with the food had so much space showing was incredible. All the Ethiopian/Etrean restaurants we have been to over the past 12 years, this was the first one where the meal did not completely cover the platter.  Each portion was about 1/2 - 3/4 cup.  

The  combination  $14.50 and shrimp $14.50 with a warm bottle of Tej $19.50 with tax $52.00. 

 We will not be back.
author: Robynn H.

description:
It was okay. I went with one friend and this was my first time trying Ethiopian food.
I would recommend ordering vegetable dishes rather than Meat only, like we did.
We had the butter beef and mushroom chicken.
They were okay- a little oily.
The injera bread god soggy under the food, but it's okay since they serve us a good amount on the side.
Not sure the food was good enough that I'd return, but I might try other places around to compare.
The price is okay.. a little higher than I would have liked.
author: Nona T.

description: Very diverse dinner option for the mission. I recommend the meat and vegetable combo. Avoid the spiced tea...it's hot water with Lipton and maybe a few other spices.
author: Drew M.

description: This place was okay, I ate here about a year ago and thats how long this draft has been in my cue, so I've been about that not motivated to go back.  With 100's of other delicious places to eat in the mission, and many fabulous Ethiopian places in the East and South Bay, why eat here? The answer I don't know. But the quality of the food is ok, and certainly a cool experience if you have never tried this fare. But if you have the food it ok, the ambiance also just ok. The most memorable part of the evening was the fruit fly that won't stop bothering us, almost empty on a week night, service lacked a certain friendliness... but great location, they could do a lot with this space...!
author: Coco J.

description: If you know Ethiopian food, you know that this is it.  The best in the Bay Area.  My family is part Ethiopian, and we have eaten at every Ethiopian restaurant in the area, as well as in Ethiopia.  The injera (bread) here is fermented longer than most places, and has a sourness that is delicious as well as most desirable in Ethiopian food. Their wats (or stews) are authentic, with layered flavors and robust spices.  The chicken and mushroom dish is one of the very best I've ever had, and their Doro Wat (national dish of Ethiopia) is spicy and perfectly constructed.  Don't miss the lamb on the bone either.  If you haven't had Ethiopian food before, give it a chance - no, you don't get bread, or a fork to eat these delicious dishes.  In Ethiopia, you eat with a torn piece of soft injera bread, made from high-protein teff flour.  You use the injera to pick up the stews from a shared central platter which is also lined with injera to soak up the fabulous sauces under the different stews.  Cafe Ethiopia is the real deal. If you want to step out of your comfort zone a bit and enjoy the comfort food of another country, you should try it.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I wasn't particularly thrilled with how soggy and drippy the dishes ended up being (a nightmare if you're eating to-go, say, in a park)... but they tasted great and I loved the service. 

Tip if you're dining out: watch out where you put the boxes , as they don't keep very long and the boxes get soaked from all the sauce.
author: Sabina U.

description:
I've only had Ethiopian food a couple of times, but this place has been the best so far in San Francisco. I ordered the lamb, and it was so spicy and delicious. I almost ate the plate.

The servers were very nice, though they did not come around as much as I had hoped for. Some people waited a while for their food, but ours came out pretty quickly.

Overall great experience and I will be going back.
author: David S.

description: It's my favorite restaurant in SF. The service is not that good, but there're always free tables and I love the food. Specially the Zigni.
author: Marcello M.

description:
This place is yummy yummy yummy.  It's also my first adventure into Ethiopian dining.  We have eaten here a number of times and every time it's delicious.  The staff could be a bit more attentive, but it's never difficult for me to get someones attention; they're always around.

It's a great adventure for dining with no eating utensils - and the communal eating makes for great opportunity for conversation (just be sure you wash your hands before you eat!)
author: Kyle K.

description: This place is WONDERFUL! If you love Ethiopian food this is the spot for you! They have combination plates for the meats and veggies from you to pick and everyone here is super helpful. This is definitely a place to try!
author: Bianca L.

description: The first time I had tried Ethiopian food was in DC. I was completely blown away with the amazing spices, meats, and eating with your hands! I was tickled to find another restaurant where I live now and was hoping for the same WOW factor... unfortunately this place fell short all around. The service was slow and inattentive. The food was bland and dangerous... Dangerous? You are asking... well let me explain... My date and I ordered the sample platter.... I took my bread and scooped up the first glob in front of me... Placed it in my mouth and had to suddenly spit out the whole thing... Not only was this a wonderful impression for a first date... I mean what guy doesn't want to see his date spit out her food? But also I had almost consumed a portion of all BONES.... Literally had no meat... Never Again. This place left my teeth almost being broken,  a bland taste in my mouth, and an embarrassment for a first date. We can check this one off the list.
author: Allie P.

description: Food was fair, not very tasty. Manager (owner?) was rude, unhelpful. In a 1/4 filled room, he would not allow a party of four to sit at a more private table, because it was for six.. Wishful thinking on his part, table was never used... When we asked to add chicken to our dish, he refused, saying we would have to order an entire chicken platter. The dish we got to serve four people was properly sized for two or three. Not cheap, not that good, would never return.
author: Robert K.

description:
This was my second time eating Ethiopian food. The first time was at Addis in Oakland and I absolutely loved it.

But this restaurant dissapointed me big time.. The meat tasted really good, but it was not enough and there were no sidedishes at all, only meat and some lettuce. Besides that the waiter wasn't friendly.

If you want to try Ethiopian food, try it somewhere else.
author: Ruud R.

description: I went here yesterday and the food was really great.  Very delicious.  Definitely on par, if not better, than Ethiopian food I've had in Boston & DC.  The portions are slightly smaller and prices a little higher than what I've had other places, but the food quality was definitely worth it.  We ordered a vegetarian combo and two meat dishes and they were great!  Definitely enough for two people.  Food came super quick (this might have been because we were there fairly early - 5:45 - and there weren't that many people, but it was still very quick).  Also, the place has cool decor and overall a great experience.  Will definitely return.
author: Lauren D.

description:
The food is good and the place is not expensive, on top of all is well located.
Try the honey wine... pretty fun
author: Giuseppe P.

description: First time having Ethiopian food. Prepare to use your fingers and have the meal family-style with one large bowl (no plates, utensils, napkins).
author: Thomas C.

description:
I was happy to find good ethiopian in the mission.  The lentils were creamy good and the beef was also done well.  I didn't like the collards as much, but everything else made up for it.  
Not over priced and good injera.  
Sadly no shiro is on the menu.   
Clean, friendly restaurant.
author: Bryanna E.

description:
I love Cafe Ethiopia! I find it reasonably priced and portions are perfect. Some of the dishes are blander than other Ethiopian restaurants I've ate it, but overall, the food is delicious. 

The service isn't the friendliness but at the same time, I never expect wait staff to bend over backwards for me or put on a big show of love and care.
author: Sean H.

description:
Good Ethiopian for SF.  All the best places are in the East Bay, but this is our neighborhood go-to.

All the standards, fresh injera. They use a blend of teff and other grains.  

The Yebeg-Tibs is getting spicier ever time we order it.  Fairly large restaurant, can accomodate a crowd.  Harar beers (lager & Hakim stout) available.

My favorites are the zigni, collards, and red lentils.
author: Ben C.

description:
Oh, we walked in just in time, but they were friendly and they took our order just as they were about the close and let us take our time eating. Food was delish. Got a couple combo plates to try all four meat dishes and both vegetarian dishes plus a side of eggplant. It was hard to finish it all but it was so good. Plenty of injera to supplement the meal. 
Staff was friendly and efficient. Great place to get full.
author: Naomi K.

description:
I am a bit of an Ethiopian food nut. It's something about that damn injera bread/crepe-ness with its sour goodness that makes me wild. Anyway, I can say with confidence that of all the Ethiopian places I've tried, this place is my favorite. 

Best dishes: If you like mushrooms you absolutely must get theirs. Seriously. I just took a group of people here tonight and everybody agreed the mushrooms were the best dish. Amazing. Also (along those lines) the chicken and mushrooms is wonderbar, too. And, for the more meat friendly, I recommend (I think) #3 or #4? It's the meat cubes one. 

Spicy Factor: I ask for it "super white mild" because this place can pack some serious heat. And, even then, it's still enough spice to make my white face get rosy. (And yes, the owner woman laughs at me and my whiteness every time I come in and say "not just mild... super white mild! Just look at me. See how white I am? That kind of mild!"). 

Also tried their beef tartar with cottage cheese. We did it rare (someone was uncool with rare beef) and it was quite interesting too. 

Dessert: Nonexistent, but who cares?? This is San Francisco! There's friggin amazing dessert elsewhere! Go down the street and get a scoop of vanilla ice cream or something. 

If you are into Ethiopian food ---) this is the place for you!
author: Heather W.

description:
I am no expert in Ethiopian food and in fact I don't have the experience to separate what is "good" and what is "bad" Ethiopian cuisine. Which in some respects is good because all I can do is say what my taste buds liked. 

I went here with some random dude for dinner, yeah random like we started talking at Rituals and it ended here at dinner. We ordered Tibsie Derho (Doro Tibs) spicy sautéed chicken pieces with fresh, tomatoes and fun spring sour bread to clean it all up with. 

Portion size was gigantic, enough for left-overs. Overall a good meal.
author: Jade W.

description:
I really like Ethiopian food, and the food here makes the grade. No complaints about taste at all.  The reason I give 3 stars is due to two things: the portions they serve (relative to their price and other Ethi spots) and the service.  

We got the veggie combo with cabbage, carrots, and potatoes, split lentils, and one other thing that's slipping my mind.  We also got the lamb.  They could have been a little more generous with the helpings in the combo for sure--especially since they charge per person, the portions should reflect the number of people. They also charge for extra injera (MANY if not most places do not do this).

Secondly, they need more people working there. The food came fast, but we didn't see our server for 20 minutes after she brought our food. We were in dire need of water due to the lamb--very tasty, but spicy!

We might be heading to Oakland for our next Ethi dinner.
author: Emille L.

description: Walked in and felt like we didn't belong. I guess the woman here who owns the place doesn't like homosexuals - or people for that matter.  Well that's too damn bad. Compared to the woman (or should I say, angel?) who serves at Phat Beets' market in North Oakland, this lady is terrible. The food was alright , but the portions were not at all generous, to say the least. We got the veggie combos, and the lentils were probably the best part, though the greens were very bland. My stomach left with a foul after-experience, and not to mention we nearly paid for two entrees what should have cost half. Definitely won't come back to this place.
author: Peter S.

description:
Everyone says the best Ethiopian food is in the east bay. That withstanding, I love Cafe Ethiopa. The spicy lamb tips are always super tender and flavorful, the veggie combos an amazing array of intense tastes and flavors.
i love it and will continue to go. There is one Ethiopian restaurant in Berkeley I would rate over Cafe Ethopia, but I look at it as having awesome options no matter which side of the bay I might be on.
author: Arin E.

description:
The blank stare and "I don't know" received by one of my dinner companions after asking what the injera flatbread was made from had us concerned that it was more of a "you don't want to know" situation, but another helpful waiter informed us it's made of fermented teff flour and other grains, a-ok! The injera that was served both under and alongside our family-style meal in lieu of utensils was crucial to the unique, Ethiopian dining experience, and had an interesting, sourdough- like flavor (it is made similarly to sourdough starter). 

As much of a fan as I am of exploring "burrito-style" dining in different cuisines, halfway through the meal I found that I preferred to pick up my food with pieces of lettuce from the bits of salad that decorated our plates, allowing me to better savor the unique flavors of the different dishes without the competing flavor of the bread.

Favorite dish- eggplant tibsie, with the same pleasing texture of chinese eggplant, but a more complex, savory flavor. 
2nd favorite- the lamb dish WITHOUT bones, and my group also really enjoyed the chicken with mushrooms. 

We also tried a tomato-based fish dish, and a dish with potatoes and carrots, great for our pescetarian friends. We elicited compliments from our neighbor table on the colorful array of our selections. I also tried the tejj honey wine, which seemed like an important part of the authentic meal experience; it tasted like sweet sake. 

Five dishes amongst five people turned out to be a reasonably priced, and extremely hearty meal.

I'm not sure I'll be adding Ethiopian cuisine into my regular rotation, tasty as it was, but it's a perfect, unique dining option to have in your arsenal anytime you're entertaining adventurous out-of-towners or looking to break the mold.
author: Rebecca Ariel F.

description: Terrible experience with the service and the kitchen refusing to separate meats from vegetables when we just ordered several combo plates and wanted the meats for some of our party and veggies for a vegetarian in the group. Also refused to substitute any of the good meats even when we offered to pay any additional cost.
author: Garrett G.

description:
The other reviews are right on par - excellent food, good prices, but inattentive staff.  

I've had several different dishes here and liked the majority of them a lot.  The Kitfo is great, Gored Gored is some of the best sauce I've ever tasted, and the way they cook the spinach makes eating my vegetables a pleasure.  

Regarding the service, it's negligible for the great food, but it does need work.  It's rare that someone greets us immediately at the door, it always takes them a minute or two to notice we are there, and then more time for them to set up a table.  If they stepped up their hospitality game, they'd be one of the best gigs in town!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Food was really good just a bit pricey compared to other Ethiopian joints I've been too.

Enjoyed the meat & vegetarian selections. The Chicken and Kale dish was delicious
author: Alice ..

description:
I came here last week with a few friends. It was okay. 

While my friends were turned off by the waitress's apparent lack of hospitality, I think I was just disappointed by the food. It was filling and flavorful, yes, but it wasn't "special," if you know what I mean. I didn't leave the restaurant thinking, "Wow, I've got to come back here sometime."

A newbie to Ethiopian cuisine, however, I did think it was pretty awesome to be able eat with my hands (and have it be culturally acceptable). Everything is better with your hands.
author: Jean F.

description:
Fresh, fantastic,. low-fat homestyle Ethiopian food--good for both diets and wallets.   We eat vegetarian here and LOVE it.  

It's a busy place at peak times/weekends but I've never had to wait for a table, because they have plenty of space, with some nice private nooks in the back for big parties. Patrons seem young and hip, but there's a lot of variety.

There are lots of Ethiopian artifacts and art to look at while you wait a reasonable time for your food. The music is subtle but the place can get a bit loud when every table is full (weekends). Still, you can alway have a good conversation without shouting.

The menu is a bit confusing but we usually get two main dishes (one with protein, like tofu or lentils) and split back and forth from the same plate of injera. They also serve a nice big pint of draft beer for a great price. 

You get 
--fresh food (freshly chopped zucchini, real spinach and greens, etc.), 
--lowfat food (you can stay on a diet and eat well here),
--decent price for plenty of food, and 
--reliably good cooking (no bad surprises like I get at most $$ and $$$ places here).

I never gain the slightest weight or body fat percentage eating their food, although the food looks and tastes rich. Also, Ethiopian spice is one of the few really good combos with tofu. Their tofu is creamy and just chewy enough--not too hard and not too soft, similar to Indian paneer/cheese cubes).

This is a home style restaurant, as the term "Cafe" Ethiopian would tell you. You don't eat off arty asymmetrical plates with micro-doses of food squirted around them, you eat a full meal off of Bakelite Chinese ware (the only affordable platter big enough to hold a round of injera, I guess). It reminds me of a home style Japanese restaurant in a Japanese mall in Cambridge, which had the best bowls of Japanese cafe food you can imagine. That place was always full of homesick Harvard students. A similar professionally down home vibe characterizes Cafe Ethiopia.

The woman who runs/owns it is a charming lady, and the serious man (co-owner? husband?) who does most of the waiting (although lately he has help from a couple of  young women) seems to have stepped out of a five star restaurant in Casablanca in 1944. Service is solid and courteous, much better than most restaurants in this price range.

We sometimes take home an order of injera (neatly rolled up) for breakfast the next day--it's great as toast. If you order takeout I would ask them to box up the injera separately (in the neat little rolls). If it's combined, it gets too steamy in the box. I don't know if they do this but they do have small boxes and I think it's possible.

My only critique--and true of all Ethiopian places I've been to--is my wish for a little finger bowl or towelette to freshen up for the process ahead of eating by hand. We always visit the bathroom to wash, but it's not the most appetizing place in any 
restaurant. If I were the owner I would get someone in to really set up those restrooms with some bright paint, a picture or two, a trash can in the right spot for disposing of the paper towel AFTER you open the door, and a nice smelling natural hand soap. Or maybe just provide some nice mini-handwipes with a neutral scent, along with the paper napkins in their holder at the table.
author: Czenzi O.

description:
This was my first time trying Ethiopian food so I don't have any comparison.

We ordered two of the vegetarian combos (3 dishes each) which gave us a lot of variety.  Everything on the plate was delicious.

I look forward to coming back here and trying the meat dishes.

I also tried the honey wine which was nice but a little two sweet for my taste.
author: Randy L.

description:
I didn't leave this place hating it, but I also didn't leave wanting to come back either.

The service was really really slow for a Saturday night and the server didn't have much in the way of recommendations for our menu choices either.  I will say that the woman who came by to refill water was extremely consistent and did an awesome job.

We got three meat options and the kale.  My favorite thing was that it was all nice and spicy... but I wasn't thrilled with the general taste of it either.  I have been walking by this place for months waiting to go with a friend who would be brave enough to try it with me and it was a disappointment.

Bummer.
author: Autumn B.

description:
