I am a fan of Ethiopian food because it presents a good variety, is relatively cheap, and is great for groups.  I passed this place on Valencia and decided to go there the night after.

The chicken selections were excellent, the vegetarian options were also good, but a bit on the spicy side for some (you may be able to ask them to tone it down though).

Although not the best Ethiopian place I've been to (best was in Chicago), this is high on the list.  It is also very affordable.
author: Anshu A.

description:
Total experience was ok but not more :
- food was not that good. 
- service was not terrible but not nice
- the place is ok. 
Compared to the price it is not a great value.
author: Wiktor K.

description:
I love Ethiopian food, usually, but the best thing about Cafe Ethiopia is that it's cheap.....3 of us ate for $37, which included a glass of wine, 2 chicken dishes and one vegetable dish. 

Bland and uninspired describes the food, the atmo, and the servers.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Ok - first - let me say that I know Ethiopian food. I have been to Ethiopia, I have eaten Ethiopian food in about 6 other countries - and I have probably eaten at about 90% of the Ethiopian restaurants in SF and the East Bay. So - I'm no newbie to this who is going to tell you about how quaint it is to eat with your fingers! Ethiopian is my favorite cuisine and I crave it weekly - seriously! 

That said, Cafe Ethiopia is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city! 

Decor - The space is clean, open, and nicely decorated. The location on Valencia can't be beat. 

Service - I find the staff at Cafe Ethiopia to be very pleasant. Sometimes a little slow - and maybe not effusive - but they are kind people. I find that a big smile goes a long way. 

Food - I think a good measure of the food at an Ethiopian restaurant starts with the injera (the spongy soda bread that all your food comes on). The injera should be FRESH! I have gone to so many places in the city where the injera is dry and crumbles in your hands - that should not happen. The injera at Cafe Ethiopia is always fresh. Next - the vegetarian options are great. I love the veggie combo and my favorites are the messer wot (a wot is a stew - the messer wot is made of red lentils - a little spicy) and the gomen (the collard greens). The potatoes and yellow lentils are also perrenial favorites. The mushrooms can be spicy too - not in a bad way - but you should be warned. I also find the meat here to be very good - my favorite is the Zigni (beef in a berber sauce - berber is a typical Ethiopian spice)! My mouth waters just thinking about it! But as a warning, the Zigni can be a bit spicy - but berber is spicy - so it is meant to be that way. The lamb dishes are also very tasty. The one downside to the menu is that they don't serve shiro (a vegetarian favorite made out of chick-pea flour).

Beverages - the restaurant carries a full selection of beers and wine including Tej (Ethiopian honey wine -- watch out, its SWEET - if you like Jewish kosher wines - then this is for YOU!) and various Ethiopian beers - I like the Hakim Stout. 

Prices - I find the prices here to be pretty comparable to other Ethiopian places in the city. Sometimes the portion can seem a bit small - but that is probably because I can always eat everything on the plate. 

Every time I eat at this place, I have that wonderful post-Ethiopian "oh my God my stomach is expanding with so much delicious food and injera feeling" - and then contentment ensues :)
author: Sarah G.

description:
A no-nonsense place for good food. No wicker stools, the decor is modern and simple. The food is really good and quite inexpensive. A single diner can have a combination plate with two (2) different meat selections and a veg, with salad.

As stated in other reviews, parking is insane around this neighborhood. Take BART and have a nice stroll.
author: Richard H.

description:
I love Ethiopian food, but the flavors at this place were a bit too intense (is that even possible?  I love intense flavors!).  Too salty, too spicy, too...something.

It's an ok choice though if you're in the neighborhood and craving Ethiopian.
author: Cat L.

description: Been coming here for over 10 years.  I usually have the Kitfo or the chicken drumsticks with egg(forgot the name).  My wife has vegan.  Always good.  Willing to serve us in separate plates (to separate meat from vegan) which is against their tradition.  Owner runs a tight ship.  Despite Kitfo being raw, I never had a problem in my 10 years of eating there.
author: Will T.

description: Really good Ethiopian food and a cool environment! You order a few dishes which are served to you on a big plate to share, and you are expected to eat with your hands per Ethiopian tradition (although we were offered utensils). We got the chicken with mushrooms and a lentil dish for two people and were quite full. The food was colorful and fun to eat. The only reason I'm not giving the extra star is that it wasn't a super cool dining experience, the inside is not super nice, although clean and nice enough.
author: Ashley C.

description:
A bit pricey for the amount of food, but the staff was nice and the food was pretty tasty. Definitely not the best Ethiopian I've had but the only I've had in SF so far. 

Honey wine is not as sickly sweet as it sounds like it would be.
author: Will R.

description:
The lamb dish number 28 and the steak number 5 are tasty. But hot!!! My mouth was tingly for an hour.  Once I got used to not having a fork I rolled up and grabbed a big bite with the spongy bread. Yum. 
I would give a higher score but the steak was a little grisly and chewy for me.  
The service came with a smile and the atmosphere was warm and inviting of conversation.
author: Frank A.

description:
This was my first time eating Ethiopian food, it was so good we ordered and it didn't take long to get served. It was a filling meal and very good we ordered 6 times I suggest that everyone should try it outstanding.  The only draw back was that there were no towels to wipe your hands off before and after the meal. I didn't know until my friend told me that at most Ethiopian restaurants they do have give them to the customers. 

The service was not friendly or welcoming they should take more care of their customers and be more open and friendly and a smile would help as well.  The only reason they got three stars was because of the service the restaurant was clean but the service....
author: RICHARD J.

description: Relatively overpriced for the amount of food, but the chicken is quite good (but be sure to ask for less spice if you are so inclined). Please note that the sourdough-like taste of injera may be an acquired taste for some.
author: Mayumi O.

description: I called to make a reservation for two people but they said that they don't take reservation for two and I said okay but I would feel more at ease if I could please. she said no there will be a place for you but to be honest I have heard this before and was not able to get a set so...I just decided to not even try this place... I wish the hosts would have just done what I asked so the consumer would feel at ease this is the most important.
author: Nicole C.

description: Food was pretty tasty but everything else sucked. We ended up at this restaurant because we love Ethiopian food and wanted to give it a try. The server is all alone with no help and I am unsure if he has social anxiety or is just an unfriendly person in general. The portions were small for the price and nothing amazing. I had to get up and go ask for more napkins and the bread because no one ever came around to see how you are doing. I've had much better experiences and would not plan on returning in the future, sadly.
author: Alysia K.

description: Got the vegetarian platter for five and it was good. Not the best Ethio I've had, but still alright. They were out of honey wine when we got there, which was disappointing.
author: Siva M.

description: Really wash your hands before eating here.... as you need to use your hands, no utensils.  The lamb was very tender and the sauce spicy, the right flavor.  I will not get the chicken as it is not much and come with an egg.  Portions are small.
author: Z G.

description:
Cafe Ethiopia is my favorite eritrean restaurants. They cook the onions to the point where I only have to taste them as a spice (it's the only time I eat onions and am quite happy to do so).

Lots of stuff has a nice tanginess to them.

My favorites are the Kantishara and the Chicken & Mushrooms.
It makes for a great vegetarian restaurant as well.

They can be rather slow to get your food to you compared to other places... but it's so worth it to me.
author: Shane P.

description:
By no means do I claim to know authentic Ethiopian food, however, this place is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city - and I've been to nearly every one on the yelp list. 

The staff is friendly. I go there semi-often and they still seem to remember my order, which I like.

My favorite dishes are: Tibsie Derho (great chicken pieces in a spicy sauce), Kitfo (raw or seared beef with spice), Tibsie Sega, Tibsie Begee (boneless lamb) and Yatakelt Kilikil (potatoes, carrots and cabbage in a yellow drier curry). Although these are my favorites, I've never had a dish here that I didn't like. Their ingredients without fail seem to be very fresh.

The decor is very bland, but once you get your food - it doesn't matter!
author: Preston J.

description: This place has been here for 15 years serving up better than average grub. We had the vegi combo. Bread had tiny eyes and was very moist, just about the best I have had. Lentils and greens were especially good and the location is right in the middle of everything cool about Valencia.
author: Steve S.

description:
We love this place!  Great ambience, friendly Mom & Pop feel, and incredibly delicious, highly nutritious food.

Whenever I need more greens in my diet, or just a treat, we order their Vegetarian Combo (#18), getting a combination of greens and lentil or pea dishes.  Everything is in a wonderful sauce and just tastes really good.  We've heard that the Teffa bread, which is a kind of sourdough, is also gluten-free, for people with that health concern.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Ok. Pricey.

Portions are small for the price. Pop music kind of annoying
author: Meia M.

description:
Good food.  I have to admit Ethiopian food is not too high on my favorite list of cuisines.  The two other Ethiopian restaurants I've tried out were sub par.  This was the first time I enjoyed it.

The best thing (for me) was their vegetarian selection.  about 7 dishes, of which I tried the spiced lentils.  Tasty.  I will most definitely be back to try their other veggie dishes!
author: Raman S.

description: pretty good food, but poor, slow service and you can only split the check with a max of two cards. also only one single occupancy bathroom with no additional sink to wash your hands.
author: K R.

description: Service was nice and maybe it's because I was in Ethiopia just a few months back, but I was pretty disappointed. The vegetarian plates had some spice, but no flavor. The lentils were also much thicker an less saucy than in Ethiopia. My husband liked the chicken dish though.
author: Cherise B.

description: Family style is the way the food is served. Basically one big share platter for everyone. You break apart the bread and use it to pick up bits of food from the platter. It was good, but I think its probably better for smaller groups.
author: Theresa D.

description: Ok compared to other Ethiopian. Good if u have an Ethiopian urge while in the Mission. 3.5 stars is the fair rating here.
author: Manny H.

description:
Really Good Ethiopian Food!
I have had Ethiopian food all over the United States: Washington DC, Boston, Denver, Boulder, Phoenix and Berkeley. The food here is authentic and compares with some of the best I have had! I really enjoy the spice level of the dishes here. Some places tone down the spice level for Americans, not so at Cafe Ethiopia. The only complaint that I have, is that the service can be slow when it gets busy.
author: P K.

description:
Standard Ethiopian food when you are in the mood.  Everyone once in awhile I get crave the more unique cuisines.  I mean who can eat Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Indian, Mexican, French, Italian, Vietnamese every day?

Need to throw in African, Brazilian, Persian and Russian some times...
author: Laurence H.

description: Tasty food but odd and unfriendly service. We had the vegetarian combo. Split peas, Split lentils, collard greens. All tasty. Injera was really yummy and light. Salad was well dressed. But we ordered a beer that was forgotten, and when we reminded them, they left in a huff, brought it to the table and basically slammed it down. Not friendly service, slow, and I noticed the floors were really disgustingly dirty. Tej honey wine was warm and sweet, not really my thing and I've had better.
author: Aaron W.

description: Delicious food! Will definitely visit again when I'm back home. Staff was friendly and accommodating. Overall a very good experience.
author: Nuraya G.

description:
I think Axiom is prolly the best i've had, not that I am the authority on Ethiopian or anything. But Cafe Ethiopia is a low-budg, yummy dinner. Just don't expect much from the service, there was only one person waiting on tables and once it got crowded we sat with our finished food for a half hour dispite numerous attempts to flag down the staff.

I wasn't too impressed with the meat dish we ordered, but the lentils were super yummy. We ordered the veggie combo with 6 of the 8 vegetarian dishes, I found the spinach to be bland, while the lentils, split peas, and lentils with potatos and carrots were the best.
author: Nikki M.

description:
It was my first time trying ethiopian food and it won't be my last! the set up might take some getting use to -- but basically you order "filling" entrees and its served on a giant sourish spongey "bread" that kinda resembles a tortilla or naan. 

oh the joy of eating with your hands and making a mess like a kid. it was fun :D
author: Jennie L.

description:
Excellent and affordable place. Have been coming here since they opened.
My first impression was not favorable since my friends and I were seated and then we waited. And waited, and left after 25 minutes.
I forgave them craving some Kitfo and we went back. The service had improved markedly.
author: Georgefromsf G.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the world.

Portions are generous,  food is fresh flavorful and pleasant, the injira is bouncy.  The interior of the place is bright, and a pleasant to spend time in.

The wait staff, including the guy who has been there at least ten years (owner?) are kind of freaks.  But, hey, I don't need to live with them, just enjoy their food.
author: Adam C.

description:
Food = I like Ethiopian food! The flavor was good but nothing out of the ordinary. Typical standard Ethiopian food. One star

Quantity = small... very small portions. I had to go get something else to fill me. 

Customer service = Horrible! It took them about 8 minutes or more to take my order. About 30 minutes if not more to bring my food. I literally sat there watching YouTube videos waiting. No check ins to refill my glass or anything. I had to hunt someone down every time I needed something, even to get the check. 

Atmosphere = seat by the window. Nice ambiance minus the high pitch gaggle of girls laughing behind me lol. 

Parking = none unless you don't mind walking a couple blocks out you get lucky and catch a spot as someone is leaving.
author: One S.

description:
Actually, I'm giving 2.5 stars.

This place is fine if you're craving Ethiopian food while strolling along in the Mission.  But honestly, even if you're dying for a change of pace, it's just not up to par.

It's sad because I LOVE Ethiopian food and the cuisine is such a natural vegetarian choice.  But the the food just wasn't fresh!  It tasted like it had been sitting around (or maybe frozen??), then microwaved before being served.  

On top of that, there's just nothin goin on in this place.  Nothing special, nothing to write home to Mom about.
 
Disappointing to say the least.
author: Angella S.

description: I love this place. The food is good, this place is not over crowded like other places on the Valencia st, provide a very peaceful environment. The Dora Wat is my favorite!
author: Guacamole L.

description: Really good stuff.  Tender beef and lamb, very flavorful. The spongy bread is good but  I got tired of the flavor after a while.  Service and ambiance are minimal, the server was efficient but not at all friendly. I would go back for the food.
author: Sunny J.

description: Love this place! Food is great. Go for the combo so you get to taste everything. Service can be patchy. Guess life is slower in Ethiopia!
author: A R.

description:
At Café Ethiopia, the chefs do an amazing job of asserting their "curry identity" through their artwork on those massive platters. We ordered a couple of different versions of the non-vegetarian platters, to share at the table. Quite promptly we were presented with two massive thalis (round platters) with various curries, lentils and veggies arranged radially atop a bed of their amazing sour bread.

The bread bed soaks up just a little of the flavors and spices, but does a surprisingly good job of resisting the wicking away of all the curry. A continuous stream of warm bread, rolled into convenient grippable configurations arrive at your table side, for your tearing and dipping pleasure. Utensils are optional, and communal dipping is the norm. It's not a mindless stream of forkfuls, and as a result, you are actually engaged in the meal, in active strategization and playful combat and the art of thali twirling. The battleship of dining out experiences!

For full details, visit: http://bitesout.wordpress.com/2012/04/04/cafe-ethiophia-mission-san-francisco/
author: Naina A.

description:
We tried to go the miranda july reading at Modern Times but the line was out the door and people pressed against the windows. Every hipster in the mission emptied from Ritual Coffee and headed here.  

So instead we went next door.  It hit the spot on a windy night.  The potatoes and cabbage, the whole lentils, chicken, beef.  Two veggie/meat combos will fill three people, though you'll probaby have to ask for more injera.

$14/ per person, including drinks
author: Vanessa H.

description:
This place was delicious. I have only eaten at one other Ethiopian restaurant (on Devisadero) but this one really blows the other out of the water!

The beef was cooked as described - medium rare - more on the rare side - Ohhh it was so tender. I don't have an issue eating with my hands - so it wasn't a problem... but utencils are definitely available for the hard to eat items.

Everything was served family style on one huge platter - it was a pretty unique (good kind) experience. I would definitely go back - I did not expect much service so it was not an issue for me... the staff seemed friendly and I didn't have the long wait times that others seem to experience... hopefully the next time will be just as good.
author: Angelito R.

description: We find this to be a great place to eat vegetarian. Two people can sample every vegetarian main on the menu if you both simply order the vegetarian combo. The atmosphere lacks pretense and It never seems to be too busy, which is how we like it.
author: David S.

description:
This was only my second time having Ethiopian food so I really have nothing to compare it to.  I tried it several years ago when I first moved to the city and I think it was at this place also.  We ordered a spicy minced chicken dish and the boneless lamb dish at the bottom of the menu page.  The chicken had heat, but I thought it was lacking in overall flavor.  The lamb dish, however was fantastic and I would definitely order that again.

I'm a big fan of eating with my hands and it was nice to have both of the entrees on one plate.  The portions looked fairly small at first, but we couldn't even finish our meal so they were more than adequate.  The atmosphere is nothing to speak of.  I don't think I would go out of my way to eat here again, but it was an interesting experience and I could see myself returning if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: Paul W.

description:
I wish I could give this place all five stars.

We walk in on a busy Friday night mostly because every other place in the area is so full that we were going to have to wait 30+ mins for a seat. Upon entering, we see three people in green aprons flying around like madmen/women trying to serve all the guests. After a few minutes we are shown to a seat and just left there for the next 20 minutes with menus.
As we were contemplating leaving, a waiter came up and asked for our order. We went ahead and ordered since the thought of eating Ethiopian food was interesting (since no one in our group had tried this before).

Interestingly the wait for the food was much shorter, and not only was the way it was served very unique, so was the way we ate it.

To break it down:
Food: Excellent (5 stars)
Service: Poor, but I've seen worse (2 stars)
Atmosphere: Interesting decorations, not too fancy (4 stars)
Corkage fee: Astronomical (1 star)
Experience: Very Unique (5 stars)

Hence my overall of 4 stars
author: Victor R.

description: I used to come to this place eat dinner and then take home enough Injera to last me a month.  I've been frequenting this place for over five years, and the plates are always delicious and consistent.  Staff is very nice as well. Must haves: Tejj-Ethiopian honey wine, Zigni, Bersin, Hamli, and Tibsie Shrimp.  I've never had to wait for a table either!  Always a great experience, and always delicious.
author: Shayna C.

description:
i went with my sister Lisa and friends Katya, Jay, Jen, Dave and had a nice big group to eat family style here - the best way to eat Ethiopian!

So Cafe Ethiopia is a great spot since it's cheap and you get a lot of food for the price.  The space is pretty wide open and chill and the staff are very nice and low key.  There's a great mix of vegetarian and omnivore options here so it can accommodate a variety of dietary needs.

Definitely will be back here for my local Ethiopian fix!
author: Gene X.

description:
"Oooooh yeah...it feels so good to be back where I belong..." (a la New Edition)

I've been on a 2+ year hiatus from Ethiopian food and man, does it feel good to be back! My old roomie from college was in town and requested a delicious meal that she couldn't get back where she lives (Montana) before she left. Apparently in good ol' Montana, Taco Bell is considered high-end ethnic food--scary, right? So I wanted to give her the gift of quality and Cafe Ethiopia stepped up to the plate.

We both ordered the combos. Winners: in 1st, the beef; in 2nd, the split lentils, and  in 3rd, the collard greens. Loser: the spinach (wah wah)---so bland in comparison to the other three ordered. The injera was deliciously spongy!

I had to restrain myself from taking our platter and turning it into a Ethiopian burrito with the injera acting as a tortilla. If I were eating it at home, I definitely would have, though. But I guess eating slowly has its benefits, as it made the meal last longer than the 3 minutes it would have taken me to wolf down the "burrito."

I shall see you again, my new lover...

Tip: If you have time to kill before or after, check out Dog Eared Books down the street--great selection of books at crazy good prices!
author: Kristine W.

description:
One of the best Ethiopian restaurants I've found in the Bay Area. The food's delicious. The atmosphere is good. The staff is friendly. The prices are reasonable.

A great option when dining out in the Mission.
author: Seth H.

description: If you're looking for decent Ethiopian food, this is your place. The sign says "authentic Ethiopian food." They have have an extensive menu of both vegetarian and non-vegetarian options so if you're looking for meat in addition to your veggies, you've come to the right place. We split the veggie combo and I also got an order of the chicken and mushrooms. All of it was quite tasty. Prices were pretty reasonable and the food was quite filling. We stopped in before it got crowded so we didn't have to wait too long for our meal. It took a little while to get our check but I've never been to an Ethiopian place where they brought your check fast. It's pretty good and if I'm craving Ethiopian again, I'll stop in here.
author: Amy J.

description:
I simply love its food. Since I am an indian and i love spicy food I truly enjoy this pace. However there are many other dishes which are mildly spiced , so people who do not eat spicy food can dine here as well. The best part is whether or not spicy, the food tastes awesome with good portion size. The staffs are courteous too.

The only con is, slow service, esp during rush hour. Sometimes even when there are hardly two tables engaged, the service is slow, otherwise good place to eat.

Reasonably priced too.
author: Neha S.

description:
When my group decided on getting Ethiopian food I was a little hesitant, afterall, not only am I a vegetarian, I'm also picky :) Oh, and I'm also a neat freak/germaphobe so the thought of family style and all of us digging into the same dish with our hands was not that appealing to me. Nevertheless, everyone wanted to go and I wanted to to keep an open mind. 

The service was fast and friendly, restaurant itself is pretty small and was crowded when we went. They will gladly accommodate large groups but it's a tight fit. I thought the food itself was simply meh to me (but a good value) but I LOVED the honey wine!  I could've drank that all night long! I also appreciated that they had several vegetarian options.

Bottom line, if you're into Ethiopian food or just want to try something new and broaden your traditional palate, then Cafe Ethiopia is a good stop.
author: H T.

description: So worth it. Each time I came here there is never a wait to get a table. The spices are yummy.
author: David P.

description: Delicious food. Just a little more expensive compared to other Ethiopian places when you compare the amount of food to the price.
author: Kassy K.

description:
low key with tasty food.  it took about 30+ minutes between ordering and when the food actually arrived.  we had to ask about when our food was going to come because no one checked in with us after we ordered.  

i've been to a few ethiopian restaurants- this one wasn't outstanding.
author: Shanna J.

description: Really good dishes, try the lamb it was seriously fall off the bone delectable.  The injera was a little dry.  Get the hot tea it's delicious.  They do not feed you the first bite, which was a little disappointing.  This place is perfect for big groups though.  Overall a good time with great company!
author: Alan S.

description:
Ready to eat raw meat? I am. Give me some kitfo anytime.

This place was actually a really good find and was so surprisingly reasonable for Ethiopian food! However, I think it kind of falls short in some aspects. I felt like it was missing some essential dishes (lamb wot, please?). This was actually not too horrible though, as it got me out of my comfort zone for some different ethiopian dishes. 

Overall, a great restaurant that really sticks to the fundamentals that defines Ethiopian food. Also, how many employees are there here? Four?
author: Richard J.

description:
I've been coming to Cafe Ethiopia for the 5+ years we have lived here. This is one of my favorite comfort food restaurants and I could easily eat here every week, except it seems wrong to not try new places. For me, Ethiopian food is the equivalent of macaroni & cheese, without the guilt. 

We stick to the vegetarian options, and really enjoy the warmly spiced lentils, greens, mushrooms and tomato salad.  I have not tried the restaurants mentioned in Oakland, but this compares favorably with the restaurants in DC where I first had Ethiopian food.

The staff is friendly and welcoming and the service is always good. The atmosphere is pleasant and low-key, the tables are not jammed together and the noise level is low enough that you can easily carry on a quiet conversation. This is not the place for a fancy date, but a place to spend quality time with good friends. Since food is shared and you eat with your fingers, you may want to carefully consider who you bring here.
author: Ruth I.

description:
I love love loveeeeee this place.
It may be filled with the regular Valencia crowd at times, but the food is well worth the wait.
Tebsi Derho is a really good choice (for me before I became pescaterian), but now mainly anything veggie will do.
Especially this weird mushy looking thing that comes with the main dish. 
Tastes like potatoe, Must be potatoe.
Oh yea, it's pretty much amazing.

If you want a fun night of eating definitely come here!  They give you some pancake-lookin' bread and you eat with your hands! Not for the easily intimidated and cleanly person. If you like to get down and dirty with you food, then folks this is the place to come.  Always great to have conversation with friends whilst you stuff your face with your fingers. :)

Great for a first date? I think not.
Great for a memorable dinner night on the town? 
Yes, my friends, Yes indeed.
author: Samantha P.

description: I thought the honey wine was fantastic. I've had it at Assab but I liked this much better because it wasn't too sweet. The lamb was delicious and I can never have too much injera!
author: Amy M.

description:
I lived in the Mission for several months last year and always wanted to try the food at Cafe Ethiopia, but never managed to get my butt in there before I left the city.  Finally, while I was back for a visit this past week I got my chance.  All I have to say is, "Why did I wait so long!?!?"  Mmm... so delicious!
Injera=awesomeness here!
I had the vegetarian combo with the split peas, whole lentils, and spinach w/potato.  It was so good that periodically over the next several hours I'd turn to my friend and say, "mmmm, lentils!" as I remembered the delightful meal we'd had for lunch.  I almost wanted to drag him back there for dinner so I could try a bunch more things!  Cafe Ethiopia - next time I'm in SF I'll be back!
author: Erin G.

description:
I have been to this place a number of time as it is the only ethiopian restaurant in the mission (as far as I know).

Standard ethiopian fare - well executed though. Good place to get your ethiopian fix if you're in the neighborhood.

The decor is a bit bland. I wish they made it a litte cosier, especially for evenings.
author: bart m.

description: Truly A-OK.  I used to live in DC where you can find truly excellent Ethiopian restaurants on U Street.  Even so, I've never had a bad Ethiopian meal, and I've honestly never had one that stunned me.  It's legume-based stews and wilted, vinegary greens over injera.  Cafe Ethiopia does everything just the how you would expect it to be done.  I will say that the portions are a bit more plentiful than I've seen at other Ethiopian restaurants, so that's a plus.  We especially enjoyed the pureed lentils and the house wine, which was not great, but the acidity went perfectly with the sour injera.
author: Pearl L.

description:
Good, basic Ethiopian. If you seek authenticity better you search out an East African neighborhood and find vittles there. The fare here was missing something somehow.

+1 for any Ethiopian restaurant though, for being the best value for hungry vegetarians time after time.
author: Wesh W.

description: I enjoyed almost every part of this meal except for the injera. It was limp and far too porous.  I write this review in direct comparison to Ethiopian food that I have had in Oakland.  Same price, bigger portions and better quality.  As far as this cuisine goes in SF, Cafe may be your best bet, but for my money, I'd hop in a car and cruise over to North Oakland/Temescal for the goods.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
It's not that this place is bad per-se, it's just that it fits the "Meh." category so well. Ethiopian food can be a delectable treat for those who have been curious enough to explore it. For vegans it's a safe haven, a delicious meal with hardly any worry about eggs and dairy when you order vegetarian. But, for first time diners, I would not suggest Cafe Ethiopia.

The food was fine, but unimpressive. The eggplant was curiously bland for the amount of oil that they soaked into it. Luckily we ordered the vegetarian combo which featured the yellow lentil puree which was delicious. The other two dishes in the combo, kale and whole lentils, where somewhat bland and dissatisfying. Also: the proportions are horrible in my opinion. The vegetarian combo was a good deal, but the order of eggplant was _barley_ larger than one of the three separate dishes that came in the combo. This might not be a bad thing because it wasn't very good!

The service was a little tardy, but maintained friendly smile. The ambiance was uneventful except for the bathrooms. You eat Ethiopian with your hands, hence the need to wash your hands before eating (especially after walking around the mission!). I actually felt slightly more dirty *after* leaving the lavatory.
author: Ralph G.

description: Got there and had to seat ourselves ... the server ignored us so we had to get the menus on our own and it took the server ten min to take our order. The portions are small, compared to all the other places I have been to in the bay area. This place gave us four pieces of Injera for three people . We asked for some more and they charged us 4$ for four half pieces. In my opinion dont go here its worth the drive out to Oakland to get more food and better service
author: Glenda R.

description: The food was OK, although portions were small. Service was good in average: one waitress was very nice, but the older waiter rushed us to order and through the meal. In fact, even when the restaurant closes at 9:30 on a Saturday night, they flipped the closed sign at 8:40 before we entered and told us to order then.
author: Alessandro Z.

description:
I'm sorry if I ask for condiments at every restaurant I eat at but I happen to like drenching what enters my stomach with either hot sauce, lemon, lime, or all of the above. Most likely all of the above. The waitress was kinda snooty about giving us extra hot sauce and an extra lemon, as if she personally took offense.

Otherwise, food was good as Ethiopian food usually is. The bread was softer and thinner than what I've had before. The mushroom dish I ordered was delicious and really flavorful. It wasn't spicy as requested though. But oh well, the lemon and extra hot sauce helped :)
author: Leily P.

description: Very delicious. The gored-gored is very tasty along with the collard greens and chicken. And they have never laughed at me for asking for a fork.
author: Scott M.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian place! And I really like Ethiopian food. The veggie combo for two ppl is the best deal. The spicy lentils, spinach and even chard are great. I'm surprised it doesn't have a higher rating since the only reason I don't give it a 5 is because the service could be friendlier. And some times the incense is a little too strong for me... but I recommend it!!
author: Akire C.

description: I think this is the only restaurant in SF that I'm a regular at-- it's cheap, easy, delicious, and increasingly busy. I hope it stays busy, as it's quickly becoming comfort food to me. I'm torn between wishing they delivered, and glad that they don't as I would probably never cook again.
author: Maggie T.

description:
I came here on a Friday night with a group of 7 people and we had no problem walking in and getting a table immediately.

The food was delicious and fast considering how much we ordered, I enjoyed an Ethiopian dark beer. We tried a lot of stuff and it was all equally delicious, both the meat and vegetarian options. Everyone left full! I also felt the prices were reasonable and less expensive than other Ethiopian restaurants I've been to.

It did take forever to get our check though, and forever to get them to come back and take our cards. Not a big deal at all if you're not in a hurry.
author: Beth D.

description: Man this place is good!  No silverware needed!!  The chicken and lamb are delicious and the greens and potatoes are awesome sides.  I can't get tired of coming here!!
author: Jeff M.

description:
"The customer is always right!", so the restaurant service creed goes... Thank god such nonsense has been dispelled--and for the good of both business and customer! Customers have their standards, and they'd hardly become any establishment's if it hasn't got its own. Customer service alone, no matter how good, does not guarantee customer frequency. What would keep the customers coming back, ultimately, is the product. Why, just the other day I was at Amoeba Music, whom I have cattily impugned in a review for their absolutely terrible staff. Catty, yes, but I'm not the only one--many of their reviews have said the same thing about those curmudgeons who work there. But their Yelp reviews are good. And I came back, and will again, exactly because they have what I want to buy.

Cafe Ethiopia is, and even looks, modest. It boasts a very trendy location which surely work to its advantage, and would keep it accessible, that is, as opposed to being highfalutin. Indeed that is one of its few virtues. One cannot come here with too many great expectations, after all, after my second time here, they really haven't much of anything that other Ethiopian restaurants don't have, except, as said, that it is in the Mission. My friend and I had the #8: two meat and one vegetarian combo--other than my and my friend being in the Mission, to see and be seen and feel awfully cool and "Indie," there wasn't anything on that plate that I couldn't have gotten at either Axum or Massawa, or any other Ethiopian restaurant for that matter.

My friend was more patient than I as she spoke in Cafe Ethiopia's behalf: "Well, it's down-time..." Exactly! So why exactly did we wait twenty minutes before a server attended to us? and another ten to get a water refill? Oh yeah, and when I walked in prior to my friend's arrival, not one server addressed me--I could have ran off with one of their chairs and none would have noticed, or perhaps given a damn!

Yeah... right... it's in the Mission... Perhaps it has also adopted the location's reputation for what I've called as its "cool insouciance." A kind of "artistic temperament," shall we say. I suspect Cafe Ethiopia is blind, and yes--insouciant, of its competition, otherwise their menu would be different: perhaps more varied, if not better. One saving grace could have been the service, but there really wasn't much of any.

For any business to keep afloat, it must be good at something. May it be an environmental, or humanitarian cause; great merchandise; stupendous ambiance; or the kind of service that is so "feel-good" that the customer will forgive it anything.

Yes, it's in the Mission. But Cafe Ethiopia, you're forgetting, there are people out there like me, by far (light-years!) more pretentious than anyone who lives/hangs out in the Mission: spilling out of size zero designer skinnies from downing too much PBR at the Delirium; just so over the Mission scene, thinking it overdone and passé; and just  smugly "been-there,-done-that." And we say, "You can't coast in it forever, baby!"
author: Rho-p O.

description:
This was different...kinda fun to eat with your hands off a large platter.

The flavors were unique and spicy. Just assume you are going to need extra "bread"...you will need it.

The service and price were just ok. The lamb was boney and lots of stuff in it that I wasn't really excited about.

Not bad once but  probably not going to go again.
author: Patrick D.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review of this place yet.

One of the best things about Cafe Ethiopia?  IT DOESN'T CLOSE BETWEEN LUNCH AND DINNER (on Sat. & Sun.).

This is important if you're on the same weekend schedule the dr. and I are on. Getting up at 4PM to find most of your food options closed is a bizatch.  (It's not my fault I'm a good sleeper!)

Breakfast at 4PM is awesome, especially if it's here.

The Vegetarian Combo + Mushrooms is the way to go.  I don't know what it is about their mushrooms that make me salivate but there is something wonderful happening there that makes me excited even before we've walked into the restaurant.
author: Jen I.

description: Nice family business! Have frequented the restaurant over the past 7 years and have never been disappointed. The injera is delicious and it's so fun to eat with your hands for a change. I usually go with a meat and veggie combo just to get a little variety. My favorites are the Zigni (Kay Wat) and the Ater (kik Wat). I also love the little lemony salad that comes with your selection.
author: Mal C.

description: Lots of vegan options! And served family style so it's easy to share (not that we shared, we greedy vegans). I got the zucchini dish and it was delicious with the traditional bread. Next time I'm trying the honey wine and getting the vegetarian sampler.
author: Sara G.

description:
I know communal food is not my fav but the flavors were great and everything was fresh.
They easily set up for a party of 8 and the service was smooth.
author: Juliet C.

description:
Came here on a Friday night after constant search for dinner at 9pm on Valencia street. Nothing! Everything was 15-20 minute wait, tops!

OK, I only had Ethiopian food three times and every time I can't stop thinking, I have to eat with my hands. Wash your hands please!!!!

The thin beef and chicken combo was pretty good but my favorite was the fish. It was best out of all of them. I suggest ordering a few Ethiopian beers or wine to go with your meal, after all, you do want to get the full experience.

My only problem was the lack of service only one server on a Friday night and maybe an expediter. Although the ambiance was quiet normal and the food was pretty good, only three stars, the service and ambiance could use a little work.

=)
author: Stanley K.

description: Tasty bites! First time trying Ethiopian food and it definitely rocks:-)
author: Lola T.

description: I work in the Mission and decided to try this place since I've been wanting to get a taste of Cafe Ethiopia.  Very simply put, yummy!  I got the combo, a vegetarian dish , a chicken and a beef one... I will definitely be back!
author: Michi R.

description:
Good food here (overall I was pleased with everything I tried though I wasn't fanatic about it). 

Nice dining atmosphere, good service, and prices that you'd expect at a nicer specialty restaurant (a little high, but hey, goes with the territory). 

A-OK, unique venue perfect for a date or adventurous types wanting to try something completely new & out of the ordinary. 

Worth a visit for sure.
author: Kai S.

description:
Really interesting and delicious food. You eat with your hands. No utensils here!
If you haven't had Ethiopian food before, then you probably don't know that they serve you a huge plate with a giant piece of "bread" on it and then add all the entrees  to the bread in small piles. They also bring a plate with more bread. We eat by tearing off some bread and then using it to wrap around some food and popping it into the mouth.
There were five of us on a Monday night, and we had the dal, yellow split-pea dal, collard greens, a fish dish and a lamb dish.
Everything was nicely spiced and yummy. Although some dishes had some heat to them, nothing seared our mouths.
The service was fast and friendly and the place was pretty busy on a Monday night at 7:30 PM. All the diners seemed to be enjoying themselves.
author: Neil S.

description:
Consider me spoiled, because I'm used to Zeni in San Jose, where the doro tibs come sizzling on a hot plate, the injera is sturdier and more flavorful, and the selection is probably twice what is offered here. 

That said, solid Ethiopian food. Wasn't a huge fan of the lamb. The injera wasn't as thick or sturdy (there's a "that's what she said" somewhere in there) as I was used to, which made eating a little more difficult.
author: Christie C.

description:
I came here for dinner with friends the other day upon another friend's recommendation.  We wanted Ethiopian, and unfortunately my friends are morally opposed to Assab on Geary Blvd due to some kind of customer service incident there.

Fortunately Cafe Ethiopia has Tej on the menu.  I LOVE TEJ (Honey wine).  It is candy.  There is, however, such a thing as too much candy.  I was so drunk after leaving that I drunk-dialed some girl and later told the lady working at the movie theater that she was "the best popcorn-server EVER~!"  But that's neither here nor there.

Here's what you need to know about Cafe Ethiopia:  Great Zigni (beef), terrible chicken and mushrooms and shrimp.  Do they even have shrimp or mushrooms in Ethiopia?  I guess when Eritrea was part of Ethiopia, Ethiopia had a coastline, but really, the shrimp is bad.  Don't get the shrimp or the mushrooms...  Same ol' Tej, though!
author: Jin D.

description: I've since returned (many times) and started having their non vegetarian dishes, and I have to say, this is easily my favorite Ethiopian place in San Francisco. I would really recommend the Gored Gored, and the chicken (#1) and the lamb with bones are also delicious.
author: Sharmin K.

description:
Ever since moving to SF from DC, I have been craving good Ethiopian food.  Went here with a friend, and it was just ok.  My main complaint is the injera - it is too thin and doesn't taste like much.  We got one of the combos, and it was ok - perfectly edible, but nothing to write home about.  

The most memorable part of the meal was the ambiguous wording of the combo item, which was choose 3 from this list.  But the list itself also contained an item where you could choose from another list.  It was like a choose-your-own-adventure story, which we needed the waitress to help us sort out.

Anyway, you should go to Assab instead.  It is a drive, but well worth it.  Your other options are Axum or New Eritrea, which I still need to try.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Quite good.  Great food.  Friendly, clean atmosphere.  

I wish I had more to say!  I wish it were open past 9pm.  The staff are attentive.  

They do not have halal meat, for any Muslims who were wondering.

It's a Saturday night, and I'm here by myself, but it's a congenial place so it doesn't bother me.  Lots of Mission-district 20-something types, but that's ok.  A few older-ish couples mixed in.  They seem comfortable.

Most people seem to be enjoying the experience.  I ordered a vegetarian dish with lentils, spinach, and potatoes.  Delicious.  

Philadelphians, see my review of the Ethiopian place in Center City!
author: Diana G.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in this beautiful city, or anywhere, for that matter. After trying a few things, I have rested upon some favorites:
Vegetarian combo: (3 items)
1Spinach & potatoes
2Whole Lentils
3And carrots, cabbage, and potatoes (not spicy)
Complemented by an order of mushrooms!!!!
Each person gets served a fresh green salad, and everyone eats from the same piece of injera (flat bread/plate) using more injera instead of utensils. Only bring people you are willing to be this intimate with!
If you'd like a drink, the Hakim (stout) is a fantastic, smooth, and toasted almost coffee like compliment. I haven't tried the Tej, honey wine, but it sounds too sweet with dinner to me.
This place can be busy, but the Ethiopian couple who run it are quiet and stoic, so don't bring a rowdy group, or you will be a nuisance to almost everyone there. 
Enjoy the fruits of the lost tribe!!!
author: David C.

description: really nice staff, cool dinning experience. Everything is served family style on a HUGE plate, NO utensils! pretty cool. I ordered the honey wine which is basically like a dessert wine, VERY sweet and viscous, it pairs amazingly well with the rich heavy food.
author: Jo A.

description:
Thursday I had the pleasure of experiencing Ethiopian food at Cafe Ethiopia in SF's Mission district. I've always been curious about Ethiopian food since I had no idea what it'd be similar to. I've since learned Ethiopian food is much like Indian food, but instead of curries, they eat stews, called wat. Their bread, known as ingera, is like a light and sour naan with a sponge-like consistency. It is proper to break off a piece of ingera and dip it in the wat, using only one hand. The flavors I experienced were nothing like I've ever eaten.

We actually had our waitress order whatever she wanted for us. Daring choice, but I have no regrets. The total cost came out to $41 for 3 people.

Lamb Tsebhi Begee (Yebeg Wat) - Tender lamb with bones cooked with hot pepper and seasoning. Although not as spicy as I would've liked, the meat was tender and juicy.

Meat & Vegetarian (Choose two meat and one vegetarian) - We got the Zigni (Kay Wat) (chunks of lean beef simmered in spicy sauce & seasoning), Tibsie Derho (sautéed chicken pieces with fresh, tomatoes, onions served hot or mild), and Kustta (chopped fresh chard with potatoes and seasoned). The beef was my favorite dish of the night. It had interesting flavors and was very lean.

Ater (kik Wat) - Split peas flavored with berbere sauce. I really liked this one. The split peas were more like a pallette cleanser between meat dishes. The texture was smooth and creamy and it had a hint of spice in the after taste.
author: Sam L.

description:
Always walk by and see it empty. But yesterday evening after dark it was packed, I mean PACKED.  We had an after dinner drink here - Tej honey wine. I was amazed to find that the wine is preservative free and naturally fermented. A wonderful way to end the evening.

The framed paintings made in Ethipoa, scenes of Ethiopians in daily life- are large, numerous and all made by the same artist.  Tables are covered with hand embroidered cloths with intricated spiralling designs very similar  to Celtic knots.  

The two owners were cool and unflappable in their calmness serving a crowd of 30 or more patrons.  

Great location and wonderful, authentic restaurant!
author: Nan L.

description:
This joint is all right food-wise but needs to step up the service. I am not a demanding diner in the least, but it truly bugs me when I go to an establishment that is operating at less than a quarter of capacity and have to wait 25 minutes for my check.  

So even though service was a lacking in promptness, I did enjoy my meal. We had the whole lentils, and the fish dish with extra injera bread. For me the spice could have been kicked up a notch or 12,  but I try to take pity on my bf who is not quite as down with the spicy food as I am. Portions could have been more generous for the price as my experience at other Ethiopian restaurants has led me to expect.

All in all not a bad spot, just not somewhere I plan on putting in regular rotation.
author: C P.

description:
I really enjoy Ethiopian food, and their vegetarian lunch combo is pretty good. But honestly, I've never had such poor service in my life. It was nearly empty when we walked in so I have no idea what their excuse was for ignoring us. 

We got so annoyed that my partner had to go to the back of the restaurant to flag down the waitress so we could get some more injera. There must be a shortage going on because they never give you enough. Even after we asked for more we only got 2 pieces. And then we had to flag them down to get them to give us the check. And by that point we were the only customers there! I guess we know why.
author: Sharon T.

description:
I've been a dedicated follower of Axum Cafe since I moved to the city.  Now I live in the Mission and don't make it over to those parts as often.

Cafe Ethiopia is a great option within blocks of my place.  The portions are a bit smaller and the prices are slightly higher but it's still a solid place for a good meal.  welll, the beef dish we ordered was AMAZING (sorry, I don't remember the name) ! and the rest of it: chicken, spinach and mushrooms were good but didn't blow me away.

Either way, it's a great place to have right around the corner.
author: Shayna N.

description:
I have averaged at least a visit every month for the last three years.  I love how thin and sour their injera is.  Their doro wat is good but you don't get the egg if you get it as part of the meat combo :(

My regular go-to is the meat combo of lamb but I pick an additional veggie dish instead of an additional meat.  I love their split lentils, aletcha, and chard.  Their kifto is tasty and their mushrooms also deserve a shout out.  I usually end up with leftover injera and food that I create a salad with the next day.  Mmmmmmmmm.

This is also a great place for a group.  

 

Dishes can be inconsistent at times and the overall vibe is very homey.  Having said that I am sure that I will be eating here again in the next month as it is a dependable tasty meal.
author: MJ C.

description:
I've had my share of Ethiopian food over the past few years, but I have to say this was not one of my best experiences.  The food was good, just not the best.

I got a combo platter: kay (beef) wat, doro (chicken) tibbs, and misir (whole lentils).  I love berbere sauce so I inevitably enjoyed the kay wat, but I've definitely had better doro tibbs elsewhere (like in DC).  The misir was good too but it didn't have enough of the berbere sauce for me.

The place is cheap, though, $11.50 for a combo for 1? Nice.

I wouldnt be opposed to coming back, but maybe I'd prefer trying out the other Ethiopian places in the city first.
author: Naoko M.

description:
I've eaten here many times and I've also tried a number of other Ethiopian restaurants in the city. This one is not the best and I do agree that the service is not great but it's not horrible either and the food is actually real good and relatively inexpensive.
I definitely recommend this place.
author: Mark S.

description:
What more do you want . . .
:: Eat with your hands!
:: True ethnic food experience!
:: Great used books stores right down the block!
:: SF eclecticism (is that a word?) right out the front window!

And the A #1 reason this place rocks, is that this is my 9-year-old daughter's restaurant of choice.  Ya gotta love San Francisco!
author: Bruce R.

description:
Location-- Great.
Atmosphere-- Suckyish.
Service-- Sucky.
Food--  Good.
Price-- Right.

The first time I ate there I ended up vomiting it all up after overindulging in Belgian beers at Amnesia.  It was delicious going down, and I have to admit it was still pretty damn good when it came back up.  Never a bad meal there in any direction.
author: Charles G.

description: A friend and I visited for the first time this week before checking out a band at Amnesia down the street. Took a blind chance and it paid off... Above average Ethiopian cuisine, quite varied and tasty, pleasant service. The spices seemed to "zing" and the injera seemed to "tang" just a tad more than Bay Area Ethiopian usual...yum! We shared fish & chicken entrees plus a veggie, all dolloped onto a big injera per the custom. We left very full and satisfied. Recommended, based on first impression. Would go back in a New York minute...
author: Jose S.

description: Good but not great Ethiopian good.  It doesn't have the flavor of the restaurants you'll find in Oakland, but if your in the mission, there's no ready alternative that I know of.
author: Sam E.

description: Solid Ethiopian food in the Mission.  We had decent service, and definitely got a smile or two.  The mushrooms and split peas were great, but the spinach tasted frozen.  Good, spicy, inexpensive, beers on tap, and definitely not a place where you'll have to wait to get in.  All in all, a good choice for a low key dinner in the 'hood.
author: Dana S.

description: A decent Ethiopian restaurant ... you eat with your hands and the food is spiiiiicy.  Good stuff.
author: Danny C.

description:
I love Ethiopian food. I mean, it's the food I seek out every time I arrive in a new city, and it always makes me happy. Every time I try a new Ethiopian restaurant, I'm always amazed by how awesome the food is. I'd never had a mediocre experience...until I got to Cafe Ethiopia. I can't even describe how uninspiring their food was. And it was much more expensive than any other Ethiopian restaurant I'd tried (you have to order your meats and veggies separately, and it adds up fast). 

And then there was the crappy service. Again, never had a not-delightful server at an Ethiopian restaurant. But the woman here (I think she was the owner) seemed offended that we were eating there. Her expression never deviated from a glare, and when my friend (very politely) pointed out that she shorted him $10 on the change, her response was almost accusatory. Our thank you's were not acknowledged, and eye contact was completely avoided. 

With the number of great alternatives in town, these people really need to get over themselves.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
Wonderful Ethiopian food.  Little piles of spiced deliciousness served on a soft, airy, injera.  (Don't forget to wash your hands.)  I can't recall which beef dish we tried, but the spinach and potato dish was excellent.  It is also served with a small green salad with a vinaigrette and something yellow (the picture on this page is completely accurate).  Good value.  About $8.50 per plate and two plates is plenty for two people.  Soda comes in cans for $1.50.  They also have a basic espresso.

I don't understand the harsh comments on the service.  They are polite, quiet, and reserved.  Food was brought out fairly quickly.  They refilled my water multiple times.  As I was leaning over the table, they said "excuse me" and gave me a chance to get out of the way before serving.  We were in a hurry to get to the Fillmore so I stood up and walked to the register for the bill with a credit card.  As I stood there quietly, one of the servers stopped what they were doing and handed me the bill and brought the receipt quickly.  I didn't try, but I could imagine that it might take some patience to get a second beer.

I'm very likely to go back when in the area.
author: Alan B.

description:
I ate here once with my boyfriend...I'd never had ethiopian food so I was quite curious on what they had to offer.

We ordered lamb cubes and beef cubes and I remember them not tasting too bad but they were spicy - not a good thing for my weak stomach!

One thing I do remember is that it did feel like a darn sauna in there!!! I remember having to take off my sweater and still sweating bullets!

The next morning my tummy was in a tizzy with food that it had never had and that was a tad bit too spicy!
author: Jade B.

description:
The menu said the beef was very hot, and I should have believed it. It was very spicy. 

Three of us had chicken drumsticks, cubed beef, and zucchini, and we were all fully satiated at the end. 

Wasn't blown away, but I liked the food and I liked the prices (about $14 a person after tip).
author: Mercutio k.

description: I thought this was really yummy, cozy, not overpriced, nice service. I just found out that Injera is healthy, so I now like it. The fish was yummy.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Admittedly, I've only had Ethiopian food once before, and that experience wasn't very positive, and kinda turned me off. So needless to say, I wasn't expecting a lot when we ventured to Cafe Ethiopia.

Upon entering the restaurant we were very pleasantly greeted, and seated at a nice table along the wall. For a Sunday evening, the restaurant was pretty crowded, with people constantly coming and going. At one point, some folks had to wait for about 10 minutes for a table, as there was no where to seat them. The staff seemed very cheerful, and eager to wait on us.

I was very pleasantly surprised with the menu selection, and the quantity of the food that was brought to us. We ordered a Chicken & Mushroom dish, as well as a combo plate that included a beef dish, another chicken dish, and vegetable dish (spinach). We also order a side dish of split peas, a glass of the Honey beer, and the Ethiopian lager beer. The food was server very quickly, and displayed very beautifully on a very large plate, for the two of us to share. Several times our waitress passed by, checking on us to make sure that everything was OK. A waiter came by 3 times to ensure that we had enough water.

I've read a few of the other reviews here on Yelp, and don't understand their experiences with the staff, as our was excellent. One thing that I did find interesting was that the waiter asked if we were interested in dessert and we declined. Less than 30 seconds later, the waitress was their with our bill. Honestly, that did make me feel slightly rushed to leave.

I would definitely recommend this restaurant, and look forward to positive return visits.
author: Jeff P.

description:
This was our first stop in our tour around the world through restaurants in the Bay Area. I never had Ethiopian food before and i knew it was going to be an experience.  When I go to places where i'm not sure about the food, i like having people with me that have experienced it before so thank God I had John,the canadian bacon with me and Karla that night.  He helped us choose foods that he had tried before.

We chose a few items and everything is served family style in this huge platter.  We got a beef dish, a spinach dish and some lentils. My favorite was definitely the beef dish.  No utensils are given. You have to use your hands so you pick up the food with this flattened bread that was oh so delicious!  

Minus 1 star for the fact that they gave Karla the wrong type of beer.  It was empty when we were in there so the service wasn't so bad.

I would definitely go again to give it another go!
author: Anne M.

description: Great food and service, and it's cheap to boot! the combos are a great deal. Get the lamb. Seriously.
author: Sarah F.

description:
The food was pretty good here.  We ordered 7 dishes (4 vegetarian and 3 meats).  The dishes that were noted to be spicy were not spicy at all...not a bit of heat to it.  I liked the lamb curry and gored gored the best.  Those two were really tasty.  I actually can't remember what the other dishes we ordered tasted like.  They didn't stand out to me; I could've done without them.  I really liked the injera; to me, eating it plain tastes better than scooping up the food.  I could eat injera as a snack all day.  

The service was ok, although it did take a while for someone to come take our order.  I would come back and order gored gored again extra extra extra spicy.  Gored gored would taste great with Indian dosa.
author: Pamela S.

description: it was fine Ethiopian food, trying some other places since Moya burned down, but really not the same.  There's so much other good food in the Mission that i'd probably try something else next time.
author: Phil J.

description:
Good beer.  Lamb cooked the way I like it.  The place was packed, and there were book readings and art exibits all over the Mission the night I ate here, so there were TONS of people on the streets, it was a great night, and great food was eaten.  The injera was good enough to be used for our dish(s), so yeah...we ate all of it, including the salad, curried potatos, lamb, and mushroom choices.  Yum!

The service took a while, but it seemed they were understaffed.  My friend described the tempature inside as "balmy", which I agreed with.  The girls in this place were all attractive, even the watress...but I guess that's typical for Valencia coming from the POV of Potrero and 24th.  

I will bring people here in the future.
author: Ben H.

description:
I've walked by this place for months wondering if it was any good. Finally went and wished I'd gone in sooner. 

The chard was amazing. I could have just eaten that and the injera and been a happy camper. The doro wat was spicy and good. Portions were perfect and the service was friendly and efficient. Honey wine was lovely as well. 
Definitely will be back, and soon.
author: Mona M.

description:
I tried Ethiopian food for the first time here, and if this is good, then I can't really imagine how GREAT Ethiopian food tastes. 

I think Ethiopian just wasn't my cup of tea. The meat entrees were just okay, and one of them was extremely spicy. Moreover, I really did not like the texture of the bread. It feels like rubber and tastes like a sponge. It has a porous texture; I particularly did not enjoy it. 

The bill came out to be a bit pricey, and none of my friends enjoyed the food either.
author: stacy c.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try out this place over the weekend.  We are both big fans Club Waziema, but its a little bit of a haul from where we live and Cafe Ethiopia is only a few blocks away so we finally decided to give it a whirl.
Overall we were pleased with the experience.  The portions are reasonable - we ordered 2 combos (one meat and one veggie), and were stuffed at the end of  the meal.  True that you may get more at some other restaurants (its true at Waziema), but the portion size was definitely adequate.    
We had the chicken drumsticks, spicy beef, lentils, spinach, potato and carrot combo...and one other veggie entree that I can't remember.  They were all delicious.  
The service and general atmosphere were both average...both were perfectly adequate but definitely nothing to write home about.
Overall this place is best described as a good, casual neighborhood find for tasty food at reasonable prices. For $40, we each had an Ethiopian Lager and left with full stomachs!
author: Nicole I.

description:
Came once with a lot of family, and had a good time eating through the enormous injera platter, but I wasn't blown away by the food.

Second time, things didn't go so well - the waitress forgot that we had ordered, then said things would be just a minute, and then the bartender brought us our check.  Unbelievable.  The food eventually arrived, and it was ok.

I wish this place was fantastic because it is a block away, but hopefully they improve.
author: Elliott W.

description:
I love this place!  It's almost always open (lunch and dinner), I can always get a table, and can shove massive amounts of spicy lentils, lamb, collards, and other goodies into my mouth with my hands and not be called a pig (for once!)  It's a great place to go with my vegetarian friends as there is an abundance of offerings and the food is so tasty that I don't mind not getting my meat fix.

One tasty suggestion if with a friend: if you both order the vegetarian sampler, you can each order 3 veggie dishes for a smorgasborg of 6 vegetarian delights--all served on a giant platter and sitting atop that sour sponge bread I love (can't remember the name, but other reviewers know it).  It's like good thali at an indian restaurant (still haven't found one that offers great thali in SF though...).

I find the service to be adequate--the food comes quickly and they leave you alone to talk for hours if you want.  The interior is not the most romantic, but with cheap Anchor Steam on tap and resonable food prices, I can get out of there fully satiated and slightly tipsy for under $15 a piece!

Damn, I'm hungry.  I'm gonna go for lunch right now!
author: ShivaMatt L.

description:
it took me a long time to try this place, even though i live 2 blocks away - it just didn't seem very inviting - but i'm glad i finally made the plunge. 

the service is a bit slow, but the owners are friendly and the food is tasty! good spot for both meat eaters and vegetarians.
author: Kristen A.

description: What a yummy find!  I got my Ethiopian "sea legs" in Adams Morgan of Washington DC, where the clusters of Ethiopian restaurant, I presume, breeds high competition and yields great authentic flavors.  Cafe Ethiopia came super close, in appearance, taste and quantity.  Very impressive.  While the food was wonderful, I do miss the opportunity to dine traditional style, sitting on the small benches and eating off of the baskets.  However, I will come back over and over for the finger-licking, savory flavors.  Very happy about this place.
author: Peter C.

description: This is probably our favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the City.  They get the spice right (we always ask for "extra spicy" and at lots of places the food still comes out too mild).  They use good quality meats.  We get take-out from here a lot; the portions actually seem bigger than when eating in-restaurant.  One of the owners recognizes my voice when I phone in the order and my car when I pull up outside! If only they delivered...  And if only they had sambusa appetizers, though I understand that's more of an Eritrean thing.
author: Danny B.

description:
I love the vegetarian combo at Cafe Ethiopia and eat it at least once a week, espeically the lentils, split peas and chard.

The meat isn't as good in my opinion, but the veggies more than make up for it. It is cheap, good, and filling! 

The atmosphere is barebones but the service is very friendly. I highly recommend for cheap take out.
author: Lynn G.

description:
I had a great experience at Cafe Ethiopia.  

We ordered spinach with potatoes and a chicken dish cooked with mushrooms. The food was excellent and the presentation was well done. There were ample amounts of the bread that makes Ethiopian food so famous. Needless to say we had more than enough food for some leftovers, which were still good when I reheated them the next day. 

Service was quick and courteous, my water glass was never empty. I love that.
author: Aaron V.

description:
This was my first time trying Ethiopian food and I was impressed with the food.

I recommend ordering the #8 as it is a great way to experiment with the food and under $12 per person. 

#8 includes-Choice of 2 meat dishes (out of 4) and 1 vegetable. If you are with another person you can each order a different meat and try all of them- this is what we did.  We had the 2 chicken dishes, lamb and beef (#1,2,6,9) and for vegetable we had Spinach and Lentil (#19 and 21). All of the food is served with injera- a pancake like bread (the taste reminded me of sourdough bread- very yummy). Everything was delicious.

Ethiopian food is eaten with your hands- injera is your scooping utensil- so be prepared to get a little messy, but it is all part of the fun.

The decor with simple and plain. The service was friendly and attentive, for the most part. I hope you enjoy your experience as much as I did.
author: Melinda Q.

description:
I went here with a group of 5 people. The place was pretty packed which was a good sign. However, it took awhile to for the waiter to take our order. We ordered combos with a variety of meat and vegetarian dishes. I think this is the best way to go with a group. The portions were decent, not too big. I think if the portions were a little bigger it would've been better. We ordered a #1 and it only came with one drumstick... Everything was really flavorful and it was fun to eat with your hands.

We ordered the Ethiopian beers and honey wine. The beers were pretty good. The honey wine is served warm and is pretty sweet. Not something we were used too. Just didn't seem to go well with the meal. I probably wouldn't order it again.

I would probably come here again but it wouldn't be my first choice to go to in the Mission.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I don't have much to compare the food to--simply because of the fact that I've only been to one other Ethiopian restaurant in my life. My review is just a brief description of my dining experience here.  

Whenever Ethiopian food is mentioned I think about culture. I think about how it is proper etiquette (just like in many other cultures) to eat with your hands. I think about how the food is communal--put in one huge platter, and shared by others.  It's so basic and simple, and yet there is something very satisfying and humbling about it. It pleases my soul each time I partake in such a tradition.

I have to say that I was overall pleased with their food and service. We had the fish (tibsie assa) and the spices they used to cook it with was a bit foreign for my taste bud. Not bad though. We also had a vegetarian dish (Yatakelt Kilikil) that was basically prepared curry style, and that was delicious! The salad was fresh and the dressing was really good. I clearly remember a hint of some lemony zest to it.  It was sort of stimulating and somewhat exhilarating. The ingera was OK, they give you lots of it.

We had the best seat in the house which was by the window. We noticed quite a handful of people passing by look in and instantly got lured by this place. The atmosphere was inviting and welcoming. They took customers in way past their closing time, which was at 9 PM. So, granted it was Friday night on the Mission, I suppose they just take in customers as they come..?
author: Cesar Thomas V.

description: Not bad, not bad. Not quite as yummy as Cafe Colucci or Ensarro in Oakland, but this was more than passable. Portions were huge and the injera very fresh. The combo meat/veggie plate is the best deal especially if you have more than two people. Our whole bill cost less than the one bottle of wine we got at Blush. The staff was nice enough to take us in right before closing time and we did not feel rushed.
author: Farah S.

description: I ducked into Cafe Ethiopia last night before San Francisco Tarot Cafe next door at Borderlands Cafe. I expected a vegetarian combination plate similar to those found at like restaurants in North Oakland. I ordered said, but I had my choice of three items as opposed to five or six at other places. There was no hummus, sadly. I ordered a cup of plain yogurt to replicate the experience, in addition to pureed split peas, lentils and collard greens. The waitress brought me a side of steamed chard when I ordered a tomato salad. I liked the looks of that so I kept it. Unfortunately, the server charged me $4.95 for their mistake, along with the tomato salad I ordered. ,Most restaurants would just eat the cost of their mistake. Not this one, apparently. The food was just alright.
author: Camille K.

description:
The food was definitely yummy, but dang, the service was HORRIBLE.

1. I walked to the counter to pick up 2 menus after waiting over 10 minutes. Mind you, the lady/waitress was right there for over 5 minutes playing with her zits (okay, that's mean, maybe she was playing with her double chin). 
2. I walked behind the counter to get 3 napkins because one of the chairs was dirty.
3.  The lady was...hmm...annoyed that we asked her to clarify a few items on the menu.

Anyhow, the food was so good, I'll forgive her.

I would order:
collar green
lamb
split peas (whole)
chicken

I want to try:
egg plant
beef
author: Linh L.

description:
I'm convinced that these people know that they're pushing out some of the most delicious Ethiopian food in the city so they feel like there is no need to offer us good service.

Its like they know we'll probably come back, because our tastebuds are mightier than our need for good service. And the prices were decent too. Just do yourself a favor and take them with a grain of salt so you can enjoy the deliciousness. It's quiet in there, bring your friends, make some noise... We talked about zombie porn! ;o)
author: Venatius P.

description:
Taste:  The lamb curry is absolutely delicious.  

Nutrition value:  The lamb curry is really greasy.  I know that its lamb, but there is a way you can have your curries not be so damn greasy.  So, if you're in the mood for greasy lamb curry this is the best ever!!!

Service:  They are not really friendly.  Straight up business... get food, pay money, leave.  Its hard to get a smile out of these people.

Value for money:  Well, it all depends if its worth it.  I keep going back cause I really love the lamb curry but with a meal, a drink and a tip it comes to at least 20 bucks.  I do love the greasy lamb curry though.  It does taste good.
author: Ramona D.

description:
The food was very bland.  I ordered some type of fish dish that was swimming in a sea of oil.  I only ate a few bites of it, it was pretty nasty.  The service was horrid, the waiter seemed to serve us as if he were doing us a favor by letting us eat there.

For 2 of us at lunch the bill came to 30$,  and we didn't have any drinks. I left hungry and had to stop off at Safeway to get a bag of chips. I have had far better service and Ethiopian food else where and would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Greg D.

description:
YUM-YUM-YUM!!

we love this place. the only thing, is that we wish the portions were bigger. you really have to order a lot to feel full (which obviously ups the bill).
author: SF U.

description:
The food is delicious!   

Tsebhi Derho (Doro Wat):  Full of taste and very saucey with chicken drumsticks and whole boiled eggs
Tibsie (Sega Tibs): Beef chunks - awesome sauce.  must try!
Hamli (Gomen): Collard Greens - personally not my favorite, but still quite good
Kantishara (Mushrooms): LOVE Mushrooms!

Tejj-Ethiopian honey wine by glass - very sweet, but has a bad after taste.  Wouldn't recommend it.

*Note* the flavors are crazy good, but this food can give you pretty bad heart burn.
author: Annie S.

description: A no-nonsense name. My kind of place. No frills, good food, quick staff. It doesn't hurt that Ethiopian is one of my favorite foods.
author: Jennie L.

description:
I like Ethiopian food, I don't like the sharing. Am I wrong for that? The lamb was super good and I was a little pissed when everyone shared my opinion and gobbled it up.  The chicken was good, really everything people ordered was nice. The vegetarians (not my friends, my friends friends.) were easily accommodated as well.   Low key, in the mission, service was very nice. The opportunity to try honey wine was exciting, it's distinctive, I probably wont have it again, but it is now officially off the list. 

Next time I am going by myself so I don't have to share.
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
The same waiter and waitress have been here since the first time I went, which was probably two years ago now.  That seems kind of crazy, but it's nice, I guess.  The service is no frills, and when it's busy, it can be pretty slow, but it's nice to have the chance to chat with your dining mates while you wait for your food.

The meat dishes tend to be a bit greasy (must be the "special butter"??), but you don't realize it until you've eaten all the meat and you start to tear up the bread that has been under it and you realize it's all soaked with grease and then you see that your hands are all greasy too and THEN you see your disgusting, greasy, shredded napkin that you've managed to destroy during the course of your meal.  The process is delicious, though.

The vegetarian dishes are quite good, especially the eggplant, potato, and lentil ones, and they tend to be less greasy than the ones with meat.  But the beef, chicken, and lamb are all great, and you should go with them, grease and all, unless you're veg.
