The bread is delicious in and of itself, and it's fun to eat with your hands and share a meal with your friends off of a giant plate.  Yay!
author: Megan D.

description:
The first place I ever had Ethiopian food in the States. It's really good and it is cheaper than any place in San Jose.

I have taken about 5 people to this restaurant, and they were all first-timers and they all enjoyed it. I still don't know all the different dishes, all I know is all of them are good :)
author: Dat P.

description: This was my very first time eating Ethiopian food! It was so delicious and I really loved the whole idea of sharing your meal. I was meeting two new acquaintances at Cafe Ethiopia, so this was a great way to break the ice, by the simple fact that we were all sharing our meals and eating with our hands. You won't be impressed by the interior at all, but the food is wonderful and reasonably priced. I decided to have the meat and veggie combo so that I could try lots of different things, being a newbie to this and all. The lentils were awesome, and the meats were seasoned well. They were nice and spicy dishes, without being too spicy!
author: Nichole P.

description:
Before I moved to San Francisco, I would crave Ethiopian food constantly. This place would always be my first stop when I would come here to visit. I've tired almost all the dishes, and never been disappointed. I do wish the food was a bit more spicy, but it still has that unique flavor that I can't get enough of. I also love the African lager they serve, although the honey wine is too sweet for me. 
The service is hit and miss. Sometimes it's painfully slow, and sometimes prompt and friendly. Still one of my favorite places in the city.
author: Robin S.

description:
I am giving this place 2 stars for the service. When we walked in, i remarked to my friend how it was odd that no one seemed to be eating anything. We soon found out why... there aren't any starters and the servers take forever to come oer and take your order. That being said the food and drinks come quickly once you place your order.We had the doro tibbs and the doro watt with the split lentils. Also got a side of the veggies. 3 portions for 5 people was more than enough. Very reasonably priced,something I am learning to expect when you go to restaurants in the Mission. 
Would I go back? We will totally have to put this to the famed Pooja 2 time test.
author: Pooja S.

description: Great experience eating Ethiopian. Had a sampler with lamb and chicken. A lot of food and nice atmosphere.
author: Michael C.

description: Awesome place. Fresh ingredients, well prepared, consistent quality, good ambience and interesting art on the walls to boot.
author: Shekar M.

description:
Pretty good.

I always clean my plate... Most of it has a really nice spice, and they give you plenty of that sour bread stuff to mop it up with...  The beers are cheeeeeap!  Which is good, if you like cheap beer, I guess....

Sometimes the meat can be a little fatty, or second rate, but I don't mind...  I just remind myself that this is Ethiopian food... So I guess I should be happy we have chickens...  

All in all pretty inexpensive, and it hits the spot...  And the people are nice, but kind of slow... but whatever... we have food!
author: Will W.

description: Try the lamb.  They can make the food as spicy or not as you want.
author: Brad R.

description:
I was here on Sunday night for a friend's send-off dinner.  He had asked us all (total of 8 of us) to meet him at Cafe Ethiopia before he flew to NYC.  It was such a smart idea.

They had us seated in the back at a round table which was away from other tables, quieter, and very conducive to good conversation (thankfully no one had to shout!).  We all ended up selecting different numbers on the menu, we had a nice mix of meat and veggie choices.  When they brought out our order, it was placed on a large round steal plate with a massive sized ingera and all the different dishes were sectioned on top of it in a family-like style.  We were also given small plates and extra ingera so everyone was able to sample a little of everything.  I really loved the veggie lentil dish (I think it was #24) and the one w/potatoes (also veggie).  The food was so good I think I inhaled atleast 4 ingeras!  A couple people had their authentic honey wine (which I've had before) and it seemed like they enjoyed it.  Lastly we split the the check equally and it only came to about $16 a person with tax and tip, nice!
author: Swetha G.

description:
I had dinner there earlier this evening. I hadn't had Ethiopian food in a very long time. 

I wasn't impressed, but the food was good. A little over-priced and the portions are small, but I wasn't paying... heh. 

Is it just me, or is everything a little too salty? Anyway, the lamb we had was cooked very nicely. The meat came right off the bone and was very tender.
author: Aromy X.

description:
I've ended up here more than normal because of the cluster of bookstores along Valencia near 20th Street, which is fine: Ethiopian is tasty and I like excuses to eat with my hands.

The injera (spongy, slightly fermented-tasting flatbread), which you use to pick up or scoop your various curry-like stews with, is tasty and toward the end of the meal does an amazing job of soaking gravy and oil up.

Try the dark beer they serve -- think twice about the honey wine. It's sweet enough to make your teeth rot.
author: Karsten P.

description:
I like 'em. I don't actually find myself over here a ton, since parking is a pain in the bupkis. However, when I do, I go to Cafe Ethiopia. It is clean, it is well lit, and service has always been good for me. Some things are strange, like only having drinks that come from cans/bottles, but that's fine. The food is what matters.

And the food always comes out piping hot and fresh! I love injera (like a sourdough flatbread. You live in SF. You know you like sourdough.) and theirs is definitely tasty. I don't eat lamb, and they don't have pork dishes, but that still leaves beef, chicken, and a good vegetarian selection. The chicken/mushrooms is tasty, and "Yatakelt Kilikil (Alecha)" [stewed cabbage, potatoes, and carrots] is MANDATORY and delicious. I always love "Tibsie (Sega Tibs)" [beef/tomatoes].  Yes, you eat with your hands, but if you have any tortilla experience this shouldn't be a problem. Just go with people who know how to share....

note: for two people, we ordered three dishes. for three people, four dishes. Then everyone gets to eat until they are full. I've never gone alone.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Cafe Ethiopia is a great place for a heart warming dinner.

The only other Ethiopian restaurant I've been to in the city was in the Haight, which I definitely loved.  As far as location and decor, Cafe Ethiopia definitely one-up's them.

All-in-all, I would have to say that the food was excellent.  The meal was healthful and flavorful.  There was an option on the menu that  let's you try three items, for about $9.00.  This was great, each of us got to pick and choose three things and sample many of the dishes that they had here.  They are served Ethipian style on a larged shared plate covered with their fermented flat bread - which I loved! 

If I lived closer, or if they delivered out here, I would definitely be a regular customer.

Definite 4 stars!
author: Shea G.

description:
I expected UN relief packages.  Sorry, I had to throw in a non-PC joke because SF people are too PC.  Service would be good if they could understand simple questions that they have already heard probably a million times.  Flash cards or practicing incomprehensible responses with a face that emotes that you understand is basic ethnic restauranteur skills.

The eggplant dish was good.  The lamb meat came off the bone easily and melded with the spices well.

Update: service is good when the woman there serves (she gives good recommendations and is friendly), the man there seems clueless.
author: H C.

description:
Not the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, i think a lot of the restaurants on telegraph in Berkeley are better, more well seasoned, but i did like the special that i had which was a spicy mushroom wat, it really hit the spot. The service was a little slow even though the place was almost empty. Also the portions were a but small, I'm used to a veggie combo being enough for two people elsewhere.  

points for the proprietor attacking a vagrant with a ball point pen, when he tried to panhandle inside the restaurant
author: Jared Z.

description:
We finally got around to this place on New Year's Day this year. (Hey, there's a lot of awesome food on Valencia competing for our sadly limited stomachs.) Service was fast and friendly, and the place is bright and clean, if not the coziest you've ever been to.

The injera was fresh and good, and there's a nice selection of 10 or so vegetarian stews. If you've had Ethiopian before, the variety on offer here won't blow your mind - I counted three wats based on various greens (spinach, chard, collards), about four legume-based ones, and a small handful of other veggies - but of the six we got to try on our veggie combo for two, all were tasty, flavorful, and fresh. A couple were a little spicy as well, although a few hotter options would be great. Overall good value, yummy food, and a good experience.
author: Xenia L.

description: Great food, lousy service. When we ate there earlier this week, the service was so poor that I can't give it more than three stars. We wound up waiting for EVERYTHING (getting a table, getting our food, getting refills on our water, getting the check) in a nearly-empty restaurant. I'm starting to realize why it was nearly empty.
author: Allison L.

description:
This was my first time trying ethiopian food.. So maybe my opinion shouldn't be taken so serious. My impression of the place was ok. Nothing special. I really enjoyed the lentuls, very spice. I love spice food...
But I also ordered the eggplant and my friends ordered chicken.. they all seemed to use the same type of sauce.. Kind of boring. The eggplant was really not special.. No special taste. I am not sure if I would go back.. The lentul were good, but maybe an indian restaurant would have a better variety with similar spices
author: Fabiana H.

description:
I was so happy to find out about this place, and will go back again. It reminds me of my former-favorite Etheopian place in Portland, Oregon: Queen of Sheeba. (That place went down-hill, though.) We had the veggie-combo and a white-fish dish. Like good Ethiopian, the different dishes should meld together well. And they did. The fish was probably the best, followed by the lentils, then mixed greens, then potatoes and carrots. 

I really liked the prices too $8-$9 per plate. And the service was very quick. All in all, it was a perfect post-climbing dinner treat. 

The downsides: The decor. It was trying to be interesting, but fell short of the homey ambiance that I think it could get with some more artwork. The potatoes and carrots. The potatoes were large chunks so you would get large bites of little flavor followed by spicey goodness. 

In short, this is a place to go for a I-just-went-climbing post-workout kind of meal. Definitely worth a vist a month or so, but not a standard like Mitchell's.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
3.5 stars, really.

An above average ethiopian restaurant, sandwiched between two neat looking bookstores.

We had an assortment of steak tartare, chicken, lamb, split-pea, potato and collard greens (I don't remember the ethiopian names for the dishes, sorry...).  Everything was tasty, though most of my standard complaints about ethiopian food apply:  bone-in lamb is hard to eat with your hands when you're sharing, raw beef anywhere other than a well-known steakhouse just scares me, and injera is more filling than you would expect.  The injera isn't exactly as sour or flavorful as I remember at other restaurants, but it was fresh and good.  I recommend honey wine, which is served by the glass or the bottle.

On a wednesday night, there weren't many customers, and we were well served and looked after.
author: Jay M.

description:
I'm embarrassed to say that this is the first time in several years that I've dined at an Ethiopian restaurant. I'm originally from DC, which has a large East African community and a plethora of Ethiopian restaurants. After eating at Cafe Ethiopia I vowed to make a regular habit of trying different Ethiopian and Eritrean restaurants around town.

One of two entrees we had was the vegetarian combo plate, which gives you the option of selecting portions of any three main veg dishes, all served on one huge piece of injera. My two favorites were the collard greens and the lentils with berbere sauce.

we got there for dinner around 7:00, so we beat the rush. When we got there it was empty and our food came out pretty quickly. But when we left it was packed so I bet those poor saps had a longer wait time than us. If that happens to you, try the two varieties of Ethiopian beer while you wait. They're good.

Definitely check this place out for a good, inexpensive, and filling meal, especially if you've never dined on Ethiopian cuisine.
author: Wes F.

description:
Man, everyone was right about the attitude in this place -- I didn't get a smile out of my waitress until she apologized for pouring water on my date's hand.

The food was good, typical of the food you'll find in any other Ethiopian restaurant. We ordered the tsebhi derho (chicken), zigni (beef), lamb tshehi begee, and kik (lentils) with a side of extra yogurt. The tsebhi derho was a single chicken drumstick, which we had to rip apart with our hands so we could eat it with the ingera. The lamb was full of little bones, so was kind of annoying to eat. I thought the kik and zigni were the best. The tejj (honey wine) was a great accompaniment.
author: Amy Z.

description:
The food was super, the service was just okay, but not bad enough to ruin the experience.   Just gotta relax and go with the flow and wait at least 10 minutes for every step of the ordering, eating, paying process.  It felt good to eat off the large plate with friends, like you were a close family or something.  When they (finally) brought out our meals, I was initially bummed by the small portions. That ended up being nonsense, as there was plenty to eat for all.  

I'm not a big spicy food eater, so it was juuuust almost too much for me, even with the stuff we ordered mild.  The cooling effects of the bread helped a lot.  

So to sum up my review: ............................................yum yum yum yum yum
author: Levi B.

description: The combo sampler meal (you get to pick three of any of the entrees) is the best deal for your dollar's worth. Plus, everything's ALREADY served on top of injera bread--then they give you a whole plateful of injera to go with! Kinda ridiculous, but also kinda amazing. I tried the split peas, chard and the spinach with potatoes (all vegetarian entrees) with my roomie. The chard was probably my favourite; the spinach/potato entree was not as tasty as I had expected. But safe to say I'll be returning soon, especially because it's a short walk.
author: Helen I.

description: I had never tried Ethiopian cuisine before so I was looking forward to it. I went with two of my friends and we ordered the combination plate which comes with 2 choices of meat and a choice of a vegetable dish. We ordered a chicken and a lamb dish and a vegetable dish made out of lentils. We also ordered a salad which was also made out of lentils. I love spicy food and I had heard that the meat in Ethiopian cuisne is super spicy. I was pretty disappointed at how mild and flavorless the food was. My only other complaint was that the actual vegetarian dish we wanted to order, which was an eggplant dish, was not part of the combination dinner. I think the best part of this experience was the bread that they give you. It's a sort of rubbery texture, almost like a dosa but not crispy. It's delicious and you can mop up all the left over curry sauce with it.  We also ordered a honey wine, which was not like any other wine I have ever had. It was definitely stronger than regular wine and it almost tasted like it was whiskey or something stronger. Overall, I was not particularly impressed by the food but it is definitely an experience worth visiting once for those who have never tried it before.
author: Neha H.

description: Those of you on gluten-free diets: this place serves injera bread made from WHEAT. I can't speak to the other ethiopian spots in the city but be sure to ask.
author: A P.

description:
I didn't really know what to think when my friends wanted to go here for dinner, but I like to try new things so I decided to go along. I pretty much left the ordering up to everyone else since I didn't know what I was doing and we ended up with two vegetable dishes and two meat dishes. We had the chicken which was really good, beef which was ridiculously spicy, the eggplant dish which was delicious, and the spinach and potatoes which were decent. 

Altogether, I loved it! I loved the whole experience. The bread, or injera, was something I had never experienced before, but it was filling and it was a fun and interesting way to go about eating food. I tried the honey wine and I wasn't a fan. It is like an overly sweet dessert wine which is way too much for me. If you are into trying new things I would definitely check this place out.
author: Carly W.

description:
The food is alright, pretty standard, nothing special, nothing horrible.  The interior is really bland.  The service is fine, a bit cold; the prices, however, are quite outrageous.  
.  
I have eaten close to 100 Veggie Combos in my day, and they generally range from $8.50 to $12 for a big platter of delicious vegetables and lentils with enough food for two moderately hungry people.  At Cafe Ethiopia the veggie platter is $10.50 per person, and when we ordered one platter for two people, we received an anemic little salad plate with three tiny dollops of food atop a halved piece of injera (?!) with two half pieces of injera on the side and a soggy bit of salad with some colorless tomatoes.  This didn't seem like enough food for one person, let alone two. I guess because I have so much experience with Ethiopian food it was very clear that this place is cutting corners and charging premium prices without providing a premium dining experience. 

I understand that the real estate in this neighborhood is relatively pricey, but c'mon... you really expect people to pay $21 for a plate of enough lentils, vegetables and bread to feed two in the Mission?  I think that this place could attract a lot more neighborhood business if they offered a much better value to their customers.  I would be willing to pay $14 for a veggie platter for two, but $21 is just outrageous, I can't understand how they justify this?
author: Alli J.

description:
I'm a pretty big fan of this place but then again, I don't have too much background on Ethiopian food. Needless to say, the two times I have been here, I've encountered fast and friendly service and literally had my first "hands-on" experience exploring the rich food and culture of Ethiopia. It's a place I would love to take my mom to and be like "HA! Now we have no choice but to eat with our hands..." 

I wouldn't go so far as to say that the honey wine is a "must-have." I found it rather flat and overbearingly sweet....otherwise, amazing. I feel like this kind of food isn't for everybody but it's a place you gotta try for yourself at least once!
author: Jessica U.

description: Basic classic Ethiopian... No frills but does the trick... Have yet to check out another Ethiopian place in San Francisco but still looking forward to this spot being on the regular shuffle of places that I like to stop by at and can be thought of as dependable...
author: Gregory H.

description:
I have been here multiple times and have really never had any kind of negative experience. The family that runs the place is really nice and welcoming, the prices are very fair, the portions are great, and the food is amazing.
I have tried a variety of things, but really love the lentils berbere, gored (beef), and chicken (I forget the name). As I fall into the problem of just getting the same thing cause I know it's good, I have tried a few others, including the fish, which was a really pleasant meal that I will order again.
I also really love the experience of eating there (Ethiopian food in general)... It has more of a social and shared feel to it... Different, but a breath of fresh air from typical dining.
author: Brian R.

description: The food was decent, definitely not as spiced up or as spicy as other places but the tibs wat like dish we ordered was pretty good. The collard greens were bland and everything else was just OK. I will say that they serve TINY portions compared to other places.
author: Maria Y.

description:
So I wanted to take the Aaron and the Philip out for a "yay you finished your semester" meal and Aaron loves Ethiopian food so here is where we ended up. And never have I had a more three star experience. The food was fine but not exceptional. The service was OK but nothing special. And the prices weren't crazy but weren't yay awesome either. Will I eat here again? Yes. Will I ecstatically tell anyone about it? Nope.
And please, please, please Cafe Ethiopia, fix your door buzzer! A loud obnoxious beep every two minutes during a meal is really annoying!
author: Stephen S.

description: I'll keep it simple.  Boring food, expensive, and NO service. Had to go to counter to order drinks and they never came to the table.  Tried to hint at the bad service with a really bad tip.
author: reza n.

description:
3 of us had dinner here. i loved the fact that for the combo, which all three of us got, we could choose different dishes each. you'll understand when you're looking at the menu.

the service is okay, the food is great!
author: Ameer N.

description:
Third favorite in my quest for good Ethiopian food.
Although, it's been years since I've been here.
author: E.Mo. ..

description: Good food, good prices.  Compares well to other more expensive ethiopian restaurants in the city.
author: Ziadee C.

description: The most sexiest food by far. It's just so sensual eating food with your hands and licking your fingers. The intamacy with sharing the food with another reaches the soul. I love the touches of spice that caress your mouth.
author: Val B.

description: I am a new lover of Ethiopian food, and I have basically only been to this one. I enjoy the food a lot, although i am sure it is not the best in the city. in fact, i know many people who's tummy hated them after eating there(luckly for me i have an iron stomach). I am writing this review about the awful service. I am aware that this city is not know for the "best" service, but the couple times i have been there, i wanted to smack someone in the face. Even if you get out of your chair, go to the counter to request more water. It still takes them another 5 min on top of the time you already waited before getting up. This happened with everything, drinks, ordering, food, check. I would not be as irritated if there was more then 4 tables filled. they NEVER have a full house, and i am starting to see why.
author: Heather P.

description: I actually don't know if this place is Ethiopian or Eritrean, but it is more Eritrean than the other Ethiopian places I know. I was told by the guy who ran Sawa (The Best Eritrean/Ethiopian place I have ever been to, so sadly closed) that Eritrean food has much more tomato, so that explains why I like it so much better!  I come here because it's the only one around here, and it has great Kantisha. I also like their  Zebhi Dorho. Everthing else I have tried has been passable but nothing to get excited about. Service is a bit faster than I have experienced at other similar places.
author: Jenny H.

description: Glad to finally cross this place off my list, after being in this neighborhood almost two years. Between two people, we split two different veggie combinations with whole lentils, split peas, chard, spinach, mixed vegetables, and (I think) pureed yellow peas. Though I could hardly tell the difference between the two greens, the whole meal was pretty delicious--there was quite a bit of food, and for the first time I didn't finish the injera that the veggies were sitting on! The Ethiopian stout Hakim was good too, but I didn't care for the honey wine, which reminded me of cough syrup.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Going to Cafe Ethiopia is a little tradition I have with some girlfriends. We always order the chicken with mushrooms, spinach with potatoes, and split lentil dishes. We gobble up the food without talking only to say how delicious it is and we should come here more often. We then debate to see if we should order more food, never hungry, just feeling a little greedy.

Service is not the best but we try to be understanding because it is a family run business and we like to see it doing well....but sometimes they just seem annoyed and unpleasant...so  4 stars for the food, minus 1 for the service
author: Christine M.

description: food was excellent, very fairly priced, good service, we will definetly go back when we happen to be in san fran again. highly recommended.
author: Mark S.

description:
Bad, bad experience.
Never had a bad dining experience in the city except here.

They mixed my friend's meat dish with my vegetarian dish after I requested it separate, then had the audacity to become angry at me when I said I couldn't eat it.   The staff either couldn't understand English or didn't care.  And I received close to no service.  Afterward, my friend got FOOD POISONING.  

I won't return under any circumstance.
author: Elle T.

description: This place is almost exactly similar to Red Sea Ethiopian in San Diego. Food and service is good, lots of vegetarian options, and there's always enough leftover. If you plan on packing leftovers, make sure to pack the injera separate from your entree because the paper to-go box makes everything (including to-go box) mix together.
author: Faith A.

description: We had honey wine, fantastic injera, and I got to eat all my date's veggies because turns out he's an adult that doesn't eat his veggie, yeah we didn't last.  Yummy & although the service was a bit slow, it felt a lot like being in parts of Africa that way, so didn't bother me a bit.  Relax people, you're already eating with your hands.
author: Cara J.

description:
This is probably some of better Ethipian I've had since returning to the Bay Area.  I came here with a group of friends, two of whom had not ever had Ethiopian food.  We ordered the Tsebhi Derho/Doro Wat, Gored Gored, Lamb Tsebhi Begee/Yebeg Wat, Hamli/Gomen and whole lentil/Misir.  

The best dishes by far were the Gored Gored and Misir.  The beef and lentils were well spiced, the beef was tender and the lentils were just right.  Whiel the Doro Wat was good, it was nothing to write home about.  Unlike other Doro Wat I have had, the chicken did not fall off the bone (probably not good quality and not fresh) and the egg (which is usually my favorite part of this dish) must not have been cooked with the chicken as it did not have very much flavor.  The lamb is a definite stay away.  It was tough, fatty and grisly, and we barely touched it.  The gomen or collards did not have any flavor.  So overall the food ok.  I would definitely come back for the gored gored & whole lentils.

My friends really enjoyed the Hakim Stout.  I don't normally drink beer, but the sip I had was definitely good.
author: Deborah H.

description: Cafe Ethiopia has the best Ethiopian food in San Francisco.  The pulse is great, meat is delicious, and veggies are very tasty.  I've never had a bad meal here.  The service is usually good, although I do recall a couple of times in which the service was a bit slow.  Overall a great place for Ethiopian food, and they're very group-friendly, too.
author: Rose C.

description: Decent food. I don't think I'll be back though. Maybe Ethiopian just isn't my thing.
author: Amanda M.

description: This was my second Ethiopian-food experience and I really enjoyed it. Came here with a couple friends and ordered the vegetarian combination platter. The food was delicious. The cafe itself is simple but clean, and I felt very comfortable. I would like to come back again.
author: Anne A.

description: Well, after dozens of visits and several carry out orders (which is a nice option too, by the way), I am starting to get a welcoming smile from the folks at Cafe Ethiopia, so why don't we go ahead and bump that up to 5 stars.
author: Josh C.

description: This is our go-to place for Ethiopian food.  There's nothing spectacular about it, so if you go there expecting to have your life transformed by the experience, you will probably be disappointed.  (You shouldn't go anywhere with that kind of expectation, really. You're just setting yourself up for a letdown.) The servers (who I think might be the owners?) don't do small talk with customers, but they are cordial and prompt, and the food is excellent.  My boyfriend loves the honey wine.
author: Jessica L.

description:
When you're so hungry that nothing sounds good and you just need to get food into your belly is NOT a good time to go wandering through the Mission with your best friend who is similarly afflicted.
But I did.
Lucky for us this place reminded me that it had been almost 6 years since I had partaken of Ethiopian food for no good reason. So we decided to get me reacquainted. 
We went with the meat and veggie combo for two people and selected a chicken dish and a lamb dish as our two meats and the chard and potato dish as our veggie. OMG! So much good food! For a mere $11.50 each we got a bunch of the fabulous bread as well as our three dishes plated on a ginormous piece of it. So good. So filling. So...healthy? I hope so! We couldn't finish all of it but we came close!  Definitely a value for quality, quantity and variety. Loss of one star for the slooooowwww service. Hopefully I won't spend another six years away from this tasty stuff.
author: Jill D.

description: Three and a half stars, okay, three and a half. Their food gets five stars, it's really good. Their service is slow as shit, though. It's not that the staff are assholes; they're great. You just have to flail wildly to get anyone's attention for such things as: a. a second round of Harar beers; b. napkins to wipe your berbered face off; c. get the check and bounce out. Don't go if you're in a hurry but do go if you want to eat some good grub.
author: C P.

description: DC has much better places for Ethiopian food without any doubt, but this one is quite good and it is conveniently located in the Mission. The food and beer selection is good. Vegetarian options are ample, filling and spicy. Service is courteous and quick.
author: Ato B.

description: There are a few Ethiopian restaurants in SF, and they're all about this good.  If you want better, go to D.C. (believe it or not).  But one thing I loved  at Cafe Ethiopia is the Steak Tartare.  I know, I was unsure about ordering it too.  And the waitress even double checked to make sure I knew what "tartare" meant :)  But it's tasty and worth a try if you're not vegetarian.  Oh, definitely order the Ethiopian Harrar Lager as well!
author: Akshay S.

description: At heart I am just a big kid and still remember my grand mother (on my dad's side) saying don't play with your food or use you fork and knife not your hands. Well there is something to be said for a restaurant that doesn't give you eating utensils unless you ask. The food is fantastic and the spongy bread is a kick this is the 5Th time I've been here and I'm never disappointed. And bad pun intended it is finger licking good. So play with your food and eat with your hands, lick your fingers and if your not dining alone lick there fingers too.
author: Tony P.

description:
smell my finger?  smell my finger.  c'moooonn!!!  smell my finger!

do you think ethiopians orginated the silly saying that has now evolved into a pop culture homer simpson anthem?

i really wondered this last night because after my delicious meal at cafe ethiopia, i could not stop smelling my own garlicky fingers, despite dozens of softsoap squirts and hand washings.

the lamb was melt in your mouth amazing and full of flavor, but the eggplant left something to be desired as it  was oddly spiced (moldy smell but not moldy) and way undercooked.  all the sides and pancake bread things were good too.  i thought the portions were fine for two people.

2 entrees and a glass of honey wine for under $27 not including tip.
author: Josie M.

description: The best authentic Ethiopian food in San Francisco.  I should know because I grew up eating it. The injera is by far the best in the bay area. Their service is okay but the food makes up for it. I recommend the chicken and mushroom dish and the vegetarian combo. It is usually not busy but avoid going there late on Friday and Saturday. It gets really packed and it can take long to get your order since they have to make it as it is ordered.
author: Teddy d.

description:
in this little of life of mine, before there was assab, there was cafe ethiopia.  now, neither my friend who grew up in ethopia nor his eritrean girlfriend give this little restaurant their stamps of approval, and after i first bit into that slice of heaven served up by assab, i too feared the day i'd end up back at CE.  let's put it this way, it doesn't hold a candle to assab, but the food, in my humble opinion, is still damn good.

the veggies are a little lackluster, but the kitfo--chopped spicy steak tartare--is solid (in terms of preparation, not consistency!), the gored gored--beef cubes in spicy sauce--is tender and excellent, and the tibsie derho--chicken and tomato curry--is actually straight up better than assab's.  they also start you off with two pieces of injera a diner instead of just one.

the service can be slow if the restaurant is crowded, but most of the time it isn't (crowded or slow), but my main complaint would be the lack of smiles.  i used to eat here at least once a week if not more and all i ever got was a curt nod of recognition from the owner (if even that).  a little acknowledgment along the vein of "hey how's it going?" wouldn't have been remiss.

anyway, if you like ethiopian/eritrean, try assab, but if you're in the mission and want good food, cafe ethiopia is an excellent destination.
author: Roshni R.

description: For some reason all the food i ate here the other night tasted like a boot. and not just a normal boot you'd buy at the boot store, but an old fishermans boot that has been soaking in a mixture of unsweetened  koolaid and lye. that being said, my rasberry snapple was tasty.
author: Arlene S.

description: Slightly above average Ethiopian food and friendly service.  And they had Mushroom kantisha, albeit a different version than i'm used to.
author: Nessie V.

description: I really like going here! Their food is solid. The service is nice. if you like Ethiopian food, you GOTTA try this place!  GO EAT HERE!
author: Mark M.

description: Who doesn't love to eat with their hands?  The food was quite tasty, yummy and inexpensive to boot.  The restaurant fills up very quickly and is great for large parties.  Wasn't a huge fan of the house red wine - next time I'll try the Merlot or just stick to water.
author: Anjali K.

description: Best Ethiopian food I've had in SF so far. The injera is not sour enough, but it is far better than the other two Ethiopian restaurants I've tried so far. The search continues... The portions are generous. Both beef dishes, and the spicy chicken are excellent. The lamb is not as impressive, but it is falling-off-the-bone tender, if a little fatty. The potatoes and cabbage are so-so, but a nice side if you order everything super spicy and need something to cool the burn. The Ethiopian stout is not bad- a tad sweet for my taste, but flavorful. One star ding for not-sour-enough injera.
author: Stephen H.

description: The food here is really good and the avocado salad in particular is yummy, but  the service isn't as good as it could be. They're slow when it comes to things like getting you water, your check, and taking your order. Nevertheless, if you're the mission, want to change it up from Mexican/Latin food and you're not a rush, then you won't go wrong here.
author: Eric O.

description:
our first time here, should have been coming here for years -- (we actually missed my friends birthday here years ago, so we would've discoverd it then, well i guess better late than never) !!!!!  now we have a new favorite ethiopian spot!!  

love the food!!!!!!!!  everything was sooo yummmeee & tasteeee!!!  

we ordered the tej (honey wine), chicken w/ mushroom  &  beef (i think #4).  though the honey wine was served @ room temperature (usually had it served cold), it was really good, not as sweet & syrupy as i've had at other places.  both meat dishes were just absolutely delish!!!!  the server placed a large plate with the injera laid flat with some greens on either side (for the two of us) & a side of the potatoes.  he then served the beef onto the injera, then the chicken.  that was cool -- have always had the entrees already on the injera.  so the way they do it -- your injera is not soaked with the entrees' juices, seems "fresh-like".  moreover, great  presentation on the plate -- the colors on the plate just looked so colorful & vibrant -- couldn't wait to dig in!!!!  

it was nice, clean, bright with lots of natural light inside.  nice & simple decor.

the only  downside was the service, not too friendly -- just straight business.   but the food makes up for the service BIG TIME!!!!!

can't wait to come back....hope to come back soon, cause my mouth's salivating just thinking of it!!!!  looking forward to trying the veggie dishes...........
author: Cindi N.

description: Thoroughly mediocre food.  We did not find the service to be as abysmal as others, but we won't be back.  The lentils and peas were clearly re-heated and overcooked, appearing to be a mushy porridge.  The lamb and beef were on-bone (OK) but very fatty and with lots of gristle -- this is food that you're supposed to scoop up with injera, not have to pick through with your hands.  The chicken was Panda Express caliber.
author: Nate B.

description:
hardy and i had yet another culinary adventure.
i'm a totally ignorant foodie sometimes and 
by sometimes i mean this time.

"where is the fucking silverware, brah?"

man, eating with your hands...uhm....kinda wack.
but i was like, "no. dont be an ignorant stuck up american."
so i dove in. fun! tasty! need more napkins!

prices? -not bad- 6 out of 10
taste? -okay- 7 out of 10
service? -wack- kinda gruff and solemn 4 out of 10

the "bread," inejra or whatever? spongy, plain crepes.
i ordered the chicken and mushrooms. pretty scrump.
honey wine? tastes EXACTLY like it sounds.

a fun and enlightening experience.
i laughed at the people that were too stuck up
and were using forks! seriously, not cool.
i believe in going with the flow.

reminds me of indiana jones temple of doom:

"you're insulting them and embarassing me.
thats more food than these people eat in a week."

dont be a priss and youll be surprised how fun and yummy life can be! 

rating 3 out of 5 play doh fun factories

p.s. i recommend the one hand approach. leaves one clean hand to grab your drink and/or text your friends and tell them that you are having tasty ethiopian cuisine.
author: JT X.

description: God. The food is 5-star. The service is 2-star. I love the food from Cafe Ethiopia but man, the service is pretty bad. I don't want/need/expect anyone to fawn over me when I eat but the service I've had here ranges from neglectful to curt to rude. I should probably just get my extra-tasty vegan sampler platter (it's so good. soooooo good) 'to go' and avoid feeling anything but warm & fuzzy for Cafe Ethiopia.
author: M M.

description: Have you ever thought to yourself, "Hey, I don't eat often enough with my hands"? Well if you have, then Ethiopian food is for you! There's tibs and wat and other spicy stuff. I'm not exactly sure what that stuff is, but what I do know is that I like it. The price is right here too.
author: Dave L.

description: Hit up this Ethiopian joint before, appropriately, seeing an amazing African boys choir at Davies.  The flavors here were exceptional and our group of 6 or so tore into just about everything with zeal.  I've only been to a few of these joints, but CE is by far the best.
author: Matt S.

description: Good Ethiopian joint on the Mission, Cafe Ethiopia serves up a solid selection of authentic Ethiopian dishes.  The vegetarian combination was tasty and filling and the price was very reasonable.
author: Apollo L.

description:
I've only ever eaten at 2 other Ethiopian places before (Zeni in San Jose and Addis Red Sea in Boston), but Cafe Ethiopia was probably the worst of the 3.  The food wasn't too bad, but the other 2 were much better for similar price.  I got take out, so I can't speak much for the experience of dining there or the wait staff, but the one person I did interact with, the woman who rang up my take out, was super non-smiley and almost rude.

I ordered the meat and vegetarian combo, with the kay wat (beef), lamb tshehi begee, and gomen (collard greens).  It seems yelpers really like the lamb, but I had kind of a scary experience with it.  It comes with the bones still in it, and I guess I had a bad "chunk" of it, because suddenly I had a mouthful of lamb and 5 pea-sized pieces of bone.  I had to chew extremely carefully to not crack my teeth and not swallow bones.  The beef was really really good though, very tender.  Both the lamb and the beef were pretty spicy, but not overwhelming.  The collard greens weren't as good as I was hoping; they kind of had a funny "old" taste to them.

The prices are either different than what's listed on MenuPages, or I got charged an extra 4$ for takeout.  Likely the prices are different.  MenuPages has the meat+veggie combo for 7.95$, and I was charged 11-something.  I figured that was probably the real price, since the lamb alone was 9$, so I didn't argue.  They took credit cards!

I would probably come here again and try some of the other meats, or maybe just get the beef dish and not the combo.  It's extremely close to where I'm staying right now, which makes it very convenient.  Given the other reviews of the service, perhaps I'll stick to take out though.
author: emilie k.

description: This is the best place for Ethiopian food from SF to the peninsula.  That's not saying much, but that's really all I can say.
author: Hanuman R.

description: Rarely do I stray away from Axiom on Haight Street, and eating at places like Cafe Ethiopia is a constant reminder why. The ambience is OK, with Ethiopian articles lining the walls and restaurant. But this is about the food, and I was hardly impresed with what I received. The waiter seemed to act like I actually offended him by coming into the restaurant. Not exactly what I would call a pleasurable experience.
author: Kenny G.

description: This was also my first time trying Ethiopian food. If you ignore the ambiance (I'm not one for pretense), I think you'll be in for a good meal. I thought the food was very, very tasty. We ate with our hands and injera, but I'm sure they'll provide utensils. We 3 ate at about 7:30p on a Thursday night and the place was about 1/2 full. I don't remember the authentic names, but we had the chicken/mushroom, the (only) lamb, and a beef dish along with the split pea dish. All food was very well spiced, fresh, and delicious. We also had Tajj honey wine: Yum! If I had to liken it to anything, the first thing that comes to mind is Indian food.
author: clark i.

description: (3.5 stars) - Not bad, but not as good as Axum. The spices don't seem as intense here, which I guess could be good or bad depending on how spicy you like your food, but I usually like a little more flavor. Best part was that it was empty on a saturday afternoon, so I had a nice quiet, un-hurried meal while watching people go by on Valencia st.
author: Tom H.

description: Decent Ethiopian food here. On meat, avoid the chicken (lots of fat) and go with the beef (fairly lean cut). The veggies were all good. They offer a sampler, so that really allows you to explore some of the more popular items on the menu. Huge portions. Acceptable service. This place isn't going to knock your socks off, but it's totally cool for a change once in a while. Would return, could recommend to a friend depending on what they were looking for.
author: Travis S.

description: I didn't think I liked Ethiopian food, but I do now.  It's fun to eat and fun to share...I liked the variety we got from the vegetarian combo, the injera is good bread, runs out fast.  That honey wine was tasty too.
author: Debbie Y.

description: My first foray tnto Ethiopian food, and, man, was I hooked.  Over the years, my husband and I would return again and again.  Cafe Ethiopia is a clean and welcoming spot in the Mission.  Tej, Ingera, bersin, gored gored, tibsie, chicken and mushrooms...all oh so good.  So good that I must gorge myself every single time.  Keep in mind: service is slow and inattentive, and parking is a bitch.   Are there better Ethiopian restaurants?  Probably.  But I don't care.  This is where I go to satisfy my Ethiopian cravings.
author: Ann L.

description:
I am no ninja when it comes to making a descerning opinion of ethiopian food. Ever notice when you want Ethiopian, it turns into some pre-planned expedition where you HAVE to go find it?
I made plans practically 10 days in advance to try this place and you know what? I was a little disappointed. 
I feel bad now forgetting the name of the national dish but I ordered that with lamb. It sort of had a crock-pot consistency to it which is nice, but wasnt jammed with slow cooked flavor. My friend ordered some beef dish that was very salty. 
I also tasted the acclaimed honey whine, and grudgingly sipped it wishing I had ordered a beer. 
This place takes advantage of the fact that it's in popular area of the mission and from what I know in yelp, is the only ethiopian place around. Overall I'd say it was okay, but kind of a lackluster experience.
I would say I'd go back and give this place one more time to redeem itself, but that's the thing about expeditions for ethiopian food, you have to go try another place....
author: Susannah R.

description: Good food tho the service at the end of the night was a little...lacking. Given that its the only option for Ethiopian in the mission its great! ;)
author: Inome C.

description: Really good stuff. Waitstaff was super nice and the food was abundant to say the least. They even brought over more spongey bread at the exact moment we ran out. Highly recommend.
author: Andrew L.

description: The food was poorly-prepared and the atmosphere minimal. The hostess we got was insulting and lack-luster, at best. We shall never return to this place which seems more for the 'tourist', than for the actual afficionado of Ethiopian cuisine.
author: Jay D.

description: YUM! I am truly a dedicated fan to this establishment.  I came here on Valentine's day, and while other restaurants were packed, this place was comfortably full.  The staff are a wee-bit distant, but i don't like to be bothered when I eat so this is fine by me.  I will of course, be returning.
author: Matt P.

description: They were packed and the service was painfully slow, but the food blew me away.  I even think that the dishes had more depth than my beloved Axum.  There is room in my heart and my belly for both.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
i'm not a huge fan of ethiopian food. i want it to be spicier. that spongy bread expands in my stomach and makes me bloated. i'd almost always prefer a burrito. 

so when my friends suggested ethiopian after critical mass tonight, i was kinda hoping the restaurant would be closed or something, but i didn't say anything. 

i like how they let you get a sampler of 3 vegetarian dishes. i forgot which ones we got exactly, but they were all good. the decor leaves something to be desired, like, decor. and the waiter was a little serious/unfriendly-- or maybe i'm just not as clever as i think i am.

3.5 stars would come in handy right about now.
author: jean w.

description:
this was my first ethiopian dining experience and it was quite pleasant.  we came early on a saturday evening and it was not that crowded.  service was typically what i expected from a cafe/restaurant - in other words, soso.  

their sponge bread had a really unique taste  it was very thin and tart.  i can't remember the names of the items we got, but i know we got some shredded beef choice that was beyond good.  i'll go so far as to call it orgasmic.  if i could have a side of that for every meal i think i would die a very happy man.

from what i've heard from friends, i expected the food to taste a lot more spicy (not hot, but more variety of spices).  the flavors were definitely new, but not overpowering or particularly powerful.  the avocado salad was superbly done!  there were four of us there, so we all tried a bit of it.  by the time it was finished, we all wanted a plate for ourselves.  and i don't even really like avocados.

four stars because i thought the food was great.  rating may change once i visit some more ethiopian restaurants to compare with.
author: Em W.

description: My mom and I love eating here.  They have the best injera I've had from the 3 Ethiopian restaurants I've tried.  My mom loves their chicken and hardboiled egg dish, I love everything else.  Sure, eating with your hands can be awkward, but if the food is good, who cares?  The service can be slow, because every time we have been there, there is just one waitress trying to serve the whole restaurant.
author: Mei O.

description: Good food. Try their mushrooms, its quite tasty and good. Their tejja ( honey wine ) is quite good.
author: Amlan S.

description: Oh me oh my, this place was delish....I tend to think meself one with an adventureous palette, but my tongue was not ready for the fabulousness of Ethiopian food.  This was my first venture into the world of Ethiopian food and I must say Cafe Ethiopia has made me a permanent fan.  Eating with your hands can be fun I swear and although they lack an attentive wait staff, they managed to keep my water glass full at the right times.  This stuff is spicy like momma used to make, so keep those water glasses coming.  I would suggest the chicken and tomatoes, YOWZA
author: Marie B.

description:
reasonably ok food, but not as good as axum.  terrible terrible surly service and nasty owners.  i wish there was another ethiopian option in my hood.

on the plus side, it is never packed, even on weekend nights and i do love me some ethiopian yummyness.
author: Sharon M.

description: We had the combination of two meat dishes and one vegetarian dish, all of which were perfectly prepared and seasoned.  This was a most enjoyable dinner with attentive staff.
author: Charles S.

description:
I used to have some roommates from Ethiopia/Eritrea and one of them used to cook some spicy meat stew - I was missing it so bad once in Mission so I stopped by at this place.  

For me it was pretty damn good food - the combo deal with two meat dishes and one vegetarian dish is simply wonderful.  Ingera here is very soft, spongy and moisturized - I believe it's genuine, I hope so because I like it this way! 

The stew with lamb is simply excellent and I can go back there so many time more only for this dish.  OK not everything is perfect but it's one of my favorite places in lovely Mission now.  

I took a cab and the driver was from Ethiopia - he said this place is not good but I don't really care actually.  But his recommendation was in Berkeley instead of SF city.  I will check it out after finding which one he meant...
author: T T.

description: I used to live above this place in mission way back when, so i went back for old time's sake. just as remembered, it was satisfying and filling. the spices are distinct, but not overpowering. the service is pleasant and fast. best of all, there are no long lines as is all too common in this neighborhood.
author: GS M.

description: If you like to get dirty and don't mind mediocre service,we's about to get down!  This place is simple, no scene just good spicy food. YES the service kinda sucks so bring your own napkins and H20 because the waitress isn't.
author: Astrid M.

description: Been here several times now and It's always been pretty good. Not as yummy as Assab but it's easy to get to if you are coming from Bart.
author: Ericka A.

description:
great food! the honey wine was ok.. it's too much like a dessert wine, and even though it is better with the food, i think it's an aquired taste. on the other hand, the hakim beer is fantastic!

food-wise, get the eggplant and fish. a+
author: omar k.

description:
the food is good enough that i made a return trip, even after i spent the first evening with a terrible stomach ache, and the whole next day in the bathroom.  what can i say, i'm not that bright.  and my stupidity was punished, after another trip to cafe ethiopia, which was delicious, again, but, again, tummy rumbly badness.  

who cares about decor--the food is cheap and it's fun to eat with your hands.  even so, i dont' think i'll make it back, but it did give me a taste for ethiopian food.  yum!
author: Nikki S.

description: Not bad.  I like most of their food (the collards are the best) and I think it's decently priced.  The location is easily accessible and clean.  However, the service is a bit slow.
author: Asteridae A.

description: There is something appealing about the idea of Ethiopian food, the idea that there is no fork, no knife, no spoon, nor even a plate.  Instead all you have is bread, and only one type of bread.  It's beautiful in its simplicity.  That being said, i wish the stuff the bread was eaten with tasted better.  Most of it i've had has been too bland for my liking.  Where are the vibrant spices?  I was less than impressed by this place.
author: Herbert S.

description: Stopped here on a whim while looking for a place for dinner with a friend.  Neither of us had had Ethiopian food more than a couple times, so I don't  have much of a point of comparison, but the food seemed decent enough.  We somewhat blindly ordered one of the beef dishes and the zucchini dish (when we tried to ask the waitress for recommendations it turned out she didn't speak much English--but she was Asian, not Ethiopian) and were stuffed and satisfied at the end.  I had a much better Ethiopian meal in a more vibrant atmosphere when I went to Rassela's on Fillmore.  But for a quick, warm, spicy meal near my place for under $20 for two, Cafe Ethiopia was fine.
author: Gina K.

description: I have not been to Cafe Ethiopia once.  And that one time shapped my opinion vividly.  The chicken I ordered was not well cooked.  I am not a fan of not well cooked poulet.  It is not good for you.  I let them know that the chicken was not well cooked.  Being a big cook myself I know that cooking chicken is a snap.  It is hard to undercook it...really!  So the waitress was so non-chalant as if it was meant to be that way.  I was so disappointed that they were not terribly concerned.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: This place was pretty good. I was leaning towards more 3.5 stars, but I'm feeling generous because I just gave some other place a shitty review. It was only my second time eating Ethiopian food, and I'm becoming more and more of a fan of it! I really liked the beef  we ordered (I have no idea what it was called - but it was the one they described as traditional and most people order). It was super flavorful and spicy and I thought the beef was cooked well. The chicken we ordered was just ok - my friend really liked it but I thought it wasn't flavorful or interesting enough. The zucchini was good but not amazing. I thought the weird pancake thing tasted better here than at the previous Ethiopian place I've been, so they get points for that. If you're looking to try something new, I totally recommend this place. Oh yeah - the sweet wine was pretty weird. It's REALLY sweet, but if that is your thing then try it.
author: Ashley H.

description: Perfectly good Ethiopian; the beef was pretty tough but the lamb was lovely. I didn't have the experience with slow service that other people had, but I'd really only recommend it if you're dying for Ethiopian and don't feel like venturing out of your hood (the reason I went)...
author: Arwen O.

description: I tried the honey wine here for the first time a while back, and I really liked it. I also like their vegetarian combo. Decent prices. Just make sure your date/dining buddy has clean hands!
author: Lucky G.

description:
slightly overpriced, boring atmosphere, mediocre service, but really really tasty dishes. the mushroom dish is lovely.

note: ate here recently and now i'm adding another star because the food is so damned good and there are decently sized portions for the price. i also highly recommend the honey wine if you like sweet drinks. honey wine: ethiopian food :: plum wine: sushi.
author: Geryon R.

description: This is the 2nd Ethiopian place that I've tried in the city.  It was okay, still not as good as Assab.  They only had one lamb dish, and it had bones so it was more difficult to eat.  The dishes didn't come with yogart or spinach and all that stuff too.  The portions aren't as big as Assabs.   The prices are moderate.  The service was not very good though.  I had to flag down the waitress for water twice.  There was extra injera in the plate already so that was good.
author: Donna F.

description: I liked using my hands. Honey wine was good too.
author: Anita C.

description: I'm no expert on Ethiopian food, but I love this place.  Generally the vegetarian dishes are better than the beef.  There's one with chicken drumsticks that's delish.   I wish they would dim the lights a little; then it could be a weekend spot, and not just for quickie Tuesdays...
author: Alison C.

description: The food was good.  I like Ethiopian and I like spicy food, so this place was the best of both worlds.  I recommend the #9 the lamb.  Although I agree with the service, it took forever to get our order in and out.  There was one person bringing out the food and only one person to wait.
author: Kit E.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco. They have a huge vegetarian menu and good Ethiopian beer.  Service and atmosphere are not too exciting but the food is worth it. It's always easy to get a table :)
author: n s.

description: Went last night for dinner. Food was pretty good but not the best Ethiopian food I've had (that honor goes to Cafe Adoulis in New Haven, CT). Service was pretty crap, decor was bare-bones. I'd eat there again because I love Ethiopian food, but I'd try some other places in the city first to see if I can find a tastier tsibi. . .
author: Mike B.

description: Yummy...Great place for quiet food for lunch --- not as spicey as i love and it could have some more greens but overall --- YUM!
author: Lisa F.

description: Have been to this place a number of times.  And have to say that my desire for it is waning.  The service---the same woman every time---can be incredibly slow.  (Which makes sense, since there is only one woman working the entire restaurant.)  At first, I enjoyed the spicy/tanginess of the lamb dish.  But the food now tastes just ok.  Pretty much the only reason I would go back is because of the lack of Ehiopian food in the area.
author: Paul K.

description: Yummy food, although not as saturated with spice as some of the other Ethiopian food I have tried.  This place is almost never over-crowded and it's a great place to grab an easy bite of delicious food if you live in the mission or surrounding areas.
author: Katie V.

description: I like this place a lot. It's not as good as some of the joints on Fairfax in LA but for SF it's as good as any Ethiopian I've had. Pretty easy to get a table and the prices are reasonable. Service can be so-so but it doesn't ruin the experience as long as you come with good company.
author: aaron f.

description: Doro Tibs are awesome! love this little place. excellent for groups and take out.
author: eric P.

description: I agree with pretty  much everybody else in regards to this place.  Food is great!  Eating with hands is fun!  Servers are sweet, just too busy to get around to all of the guests in a timely manner.  Will mosdef go again!
author: Rikki D.

description: The lamb, chicken, and beef dishes were amazing.  The veggie dishes were just ok, and the kitfo was pretty good.  Not a bad place!
author: Kryzak K.

description: very good food!  the tomato salad was different than I usually get at Ethiopian restaurants, more spicy, but it was excellent.
author: Davis V.

description: Good food.  Good prices.  Nice location.  i would have given this place 4 stars if it wasn't for the fact that there is only 1 person serving and taking orders.  so it takes a while to get your orders in and what not, but the food arrives promptly after that and is worth the wait :)
author: Puchu ..

description: Purty yummy grub especially when you have the need to simply eat with your hands. I think that this could be a good first date stop just cause being so messy when you first meet really breaks the ice. Well, maybe..My lovely friend and I shared a vegetarian combination platter and left full, happy and it didn't break the piggy bank. I am also a glutton for honey wine and it seems that I can't find it anywhere but Ethiopian restaurants. Service was alright. The waitress was nice and honestly I don't care if someone smiles or not but (just a friendly reminder it does take more muscles to frown then smile, so put on those happy faces) halfway through our meal it did get rather busy and she was the only one there running around like a chicken with her head chopped off. I think that could put anyone in a bad mood sometimes.
author: Eryn L.

description: I'm no Ethiopian expert. We've only had Ethiopian 3-4 times but we've been really satisfied everytime. This joint was no exception. I wish I could remember the name of the meat dish that was heavy on spice and cumin. I had it once and it was too good to describe.
author: Andy L.

description:
One of my top 2 favorite ethiopian places in San Francisco, tied with Axum in the lower haight, which has slightly better ambiance.  Recommendations:  doro tibs (chicken tibs) and yellow split pea dish- the best, you will want more.

really friendly service, never a crowd or a wait. Delicious food.
author: Mic L.

description: Yeah, the service can be lousy but the vegetarian dishes are great.  Love the texture of the injera and like the family style way that the food is served.  Definitely order some honey wine, goes great with the herbs/spices in the food.
author: Patrice D.

description: It was an interesting food experience.  My first time having Ethiopian food.  The service was a tad below par and the food was aight.  The honey wine was the shit.  I had more fun with my friends laughing about Lovefest than eating the food.
author: Ann M.

description:
This was my first time eating at an Ethiopian restaurant, and I must say, I was a bit surprised because it was NOTHING like I expected! The food was okay, it was a bit too spicy for my liking, but I would mind having it again. The only part of the dinner experience that scared me away was the bread (Ingera). It tasted like cold rubber-dough, and kind of made me nauseous.  It's basically a pancake-rubbery textured bread that you use to dip and eat the main dishes with. Note: there are no spoons/forks/knives, although I'm sure you could ask them and they'd give you some.

I give this place 3 stars because aside from bread, everything else was mediocre. Pricing is okay, and customer service is okay.
author: Amber M.

description: after a horrible dining exp at another restaurant, this joint was able change my mind on ethiopian cuisine.  food was decent.  best dish was the mushroom dish.  still not a big fan though, as service wasn't really all there, just bare basics...
author: Ethan L.

description:
We usually go here for our friday afterwork dinner. My wife loves this place. It is value priced for an ethiopian restaurant. She hates lamb, but loves it here....go figure. 

Service can be spotty as they get understaffed when it gets crowded.

Get your food in the family platter, clean your hands, and start stuffing yourself!
author: Rod A.

description: Cafe Ethiopia is not only my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city but also my favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  The food is always high quality and excellent.  The beef tibsie is the best!  The owners are an amazing family... you can feel the love in their cooking.  Everyone should try this restaurant once.  You won't be able to stop yourself from going back.
author: Brandi D.

description: I'm always momentarily disconcerted when I walk into Cafe Ethiopia because its usually sparse and more than half empty. Then I remember: I've been here before. It's good. It's cheap. And the whole more than half empty thing? Good for not having to wait. Some reviewers have mentioned bad service and while it isn't perfect, it's always been fine enough. I would recommend it, especially if you don't feel like waiting to be seated for an hour at Dosa et al.
author: Sasha L.

description:
Great service, authentic food (well, I've never actually been to Ethiopia, but the Ethiopian food I had in Tanzania tasted just like this place), and just-right portions.  

When i want cheap ethiopian food, I always wind up here
author: Andrew G.

description: This is absolutely the BEST Ethiopian food in San Francisco.  The food is top-notch, and the service is friendly.  This is a local, family-owned business, and the love really shows.
author: SL K.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city. Maybe my favorite restaurant in general. I've been coming to this restaurant for over 7 years now. Everything is delicious! I really like the lamb. And you really can't go wrong with the vegetarian combo. The potato/carrot stew, the bebere lentils, and the collard greens are awesome. Also, its barely ever crowded. And the service is good. Basically an all around fabulous restaurant.
author: Maia B.

description: Well. I always get the veggie combo to go. It is so delicious with (in order of favorite) yellow lentils, red lentils, potato/carrot, greens and salad. I have to have it. They know this. They know me. This time they gave me red lentils and a stupid salad. For over 10 bucks. I was sad when I opened the bread envelope to this sad sight.
author: Schnack W.

description: truly stellar!   although the decor is not particularly memorable at this lil valencia treasure, the menu is a plethora of ethiopian delights. the meats are succulent and flavorful, the injera is deliciously spongey, there is a variety of legume dishes and the greens are wonderful.  IF YOU HAVE NOT HAD ETHIOPIAN MAKE THIS YOUR VIRGIN ATTEMPT!! a must for people who like to use their hands.
author: Ligaya T.

description: A great place, welcoming hosts, amazing food...try the honey wine.
author: Maria G.

description: Waitress was very nice.  Excellent spices.  Everything I tried was delicious.  Too pricey though.  Each dish was kind of small, so order several items.
author: Tuesday J.

description: I love this place!  I've eaten here several times and never been disappointed.  The flavors are full and unique, and the portions are just right.  I recommend going with a group so you can order family style, and try all of their delicious items.
author: Libby R.

description: Eh - I am basing this review on take out food, but what I got was very dry, not too spicy, and the greens were not tasty at all - in fact i couldn't eat them! the spinach was ok, and the chicken was ok, as were the lentils. overall not a very satisfying meal. With all the good options around, I may not come here again.
author: wildcat g.

description: The place is not pretentious, and there is it's charm. You never expect anything spectacular, but whenever you dine there, you are pleasantly surprised. The food is delicious, a little too hot for me, though, and the relation portion/price is incredible. I enjoy their service, because you'll never be bothered by some questions while your mouth is full of food.
author: Snezana A.

description: I've been wanting to try Ethiopian food for years, even though I had no idea what it would be like at all.  I just love to try new things...  I finally got to!  My first time on Valencia st (which I didn't get to explore fully) I foundCafe Ethiopia.  My friends and I all had the combo meal, where you can choose any two meat dishes and a veggie dish (there are a few exceptions you cant choose for this) and you also get a salad and bread.  There's also a vegetarian combo meal as well, or you can just get one.  The whole plate comes lined with the grey, spongy Ethiopian bread, and you use that, and your hands to eat.  Yes, you can ask for a  fork too.  I had the chicken with tomatoes and onion, which came all cut up and was pretty good.  I also had the spicy beef which was also all cut up and really yummy, the best one there.  The spinach was good too, but not spectacular.  Others had the other greens, which they loved.  This was a really filling meal, for under $10, nice and tasty.  Don't order the peach iced tea though, it's just a bottle of Snapple, and the Italian soda is made inconsistently so you never know how it will taste.
author: Merredith L.

description: people hype up axum(sp?) in the lower haight, but they've got nothing on the ethiopian cafe. so, a couple of the servers, who i'm guessing are the owners will stare blankly at you and barely speak more than two words, but who cares? they handle it, and with so much more flavor.
author: Angie B.

description: Day one. You and I we don't agree. Four at the table and looking tawdry, I'm sitting with my hands in a shadow play - a jittery jaundiced expression sinks to my face as I remember the night in replayed haste. Pass the kitfo, dear. Day two and we're five at a square. A flurry of hands tearing at soured tarp and mixed greens. The kid with the hair makes mention of the fact these portions aren't kindly reflective of their origins. "Come on ya'll - they're so damn skinny!" he rambles on with that Southern aplomb. Never one to find solace in a single spoken misnomer, he runs for round two. Don't run, love - this goes deep. His hand to the chicken cubes, a sly swipe and his mouth primes - "well kids, so there's this porn site dedicated to milkshakes..." (with that I'll let those thoughts run a train, you've been spared dear reader). And now we come to day three. Fifty-four times two? No - I'm through.
author: Marc M.

description: this is my favorite ethiopian place in san francisco.  i've been coming here for years and the food has been consistently delicious.  there are great meat selections ( i like the 2 and 6) and plenty of vegetarian options.  i could drink the honey wine by the bottle  and the harar beer is really good as well.  on the down side it can get busy some nights and the service can get a little slow, but this place is literally mom and pop so i don't mind waiting for my 2,6,21 combo on a busy night.
author: Lisa T.

description: First time having Ethiopian food. I thought the stews were tasty...but eating with my hands is uncomfortable for me. Don't get me wrong, I love to eat hamburgers and crab, and other finger foods...but using the traditional injera (flat, spongy bread) to scoop up stew was too messy, and wasn't worth the trouble for the food. My friend said the honey wine was too sweet for her taste, but if you like sweets, try the honey wine.
author: DT l.

description: OK - maybe I'm just lucky, but the 2 times I visited Cafe Ethiopia, I had nothing but the best dining experience, both from a food and service point-of-view. There was no sign of the antipathy or lack of interest from the waitstaff that other reviewers pointed out. On both times, we were seated promptly (mind you, we usually eat before 8 pm), and we did not have to "flail our arms" to get attention. 4 dishes for 4 people seemed to have been just right. We felt neither overly full nor starved. Memorable dishes were the chicken drumsticks (HOT!) and lamb (a little bony but good). I love the presentation on a giant enamel on metal plate with an underlay of the spongy bread. The spongy bread soaks up all the great juices, so don't leave it uneaten. It's the best part. We also liked the Jamaican Ginger Beer and the Ethiopian beer (believe me, you'll need them if you opt for the hotter dishes.) I also recommend strolling to the Bombay Ice Cream place down the block (towards 16th Street) for dessert. It's a great way to finish the meal.
author: Rey L.

description: Really good food. Not the largest portions, but reasonable. Service could be a little more cheerful. Overall - a definite thumbs up.
author: Victoria A.
